Manager.description: Dear @moxie0, as much as I enjoy using TextSecure as a complete replacement for the standard SMS app, I am not happy with the registration process for the Push-Service of TextSecure. To be specific, I am running AOKP and TextSecure tells me that registering with the Push-Service is not possible without having the Google PlayStore-App installed. To be very clear about this: Google Play will NEVER EVER gain permission to land on my phone. The way I see it, being required to install Google Play (in my eyes one of the most dangerous privacy-breaking apps out there) just to be able to use the Push-Service of TextSecure (which focuses on PRIVACY) is like a snake biting its own tail. I guess TextSecure utiltizes Google Cloud Messaging (GCM), and as such Google Play is "absolutely necessary", am I right? Don't get me wrong: Using TextSecure feels awesome. It just does feel that way leaving WhatsApp behind and knowing that TextSecure is being recommended by The Guardian Project and can be safely relied on to protect my data. But having to have Google Play just feels wrong. My intention is to DITCH Google completely (except for Android Custom ROMs) in the long run, not creating yet another tie for myself. So why don't we make an effort to find an alternative for this crappy Google Cloud Messaging?
Manager.title: Push-Service for Custom ROMs without GCM

Manager.description: Hi, I meant not to be crude with the title, just direct. As it is now, if you want to use the data/IM channel you have to associate TextSecure with your mobile number. I realize that "data channel" refers to mobile data plan, which of course should require a phone number, but if userperson wishes to use TextSecure over wifi purely as an IM, it is bizarre to ask for phone number verification. So, at this point I'd like to suggest a "wifi only" option at hangin' out with the setup wizard time, wherein no number is asked for. Shouldn't IM over wifi, which has no technical need for a number, be the option that does not request it for setup? Obviously mobile communication must; but wifi has no justifiable reason to. I hope that requesting a number isn't considered an "anti-abuse" measure, as if users who have accounts with telcos are sweet little darlings who'd nary hurt a fly, but wifi users are criminals from the wrong side of the tracks; Telegram seems to do this too, it sucks. If it's just about spam accounts, there are many ways to demand "proof of work" from a user. To use someone's account with a telco to verify that they are an actual individual sort of flies in the face of the modern countersurveillance movement. Thanks for your excellent work, thanks for the new IM feature which is awesome, and thanks for reading.
Manager.title: number verification requirement seems back-asswards

Manager.description: I. Introduction Currently near consensus has been reached in these issues about implementing a visual security model in TS: #910, #945, #766 and #741. In my oppinion this model has some problems which I'd like discuss here and propose a different model. I created this issue because right now there is no chance to change the course of the discussion in the mentioned issues. So I chose to not interfere any further, let the participants improve their model and work on an alternative model separately. II. Criticism of the proposed model This is the visual model as proposed in the aforementioned issues. Contact list I had to make this up myself based on #741. And yes, this has been done with MS Paint: Messaging window Message history As far as I know this is still missing, at least I didn't find a specific issue about it and therefore didn't find any screenshots. Discussion There is no coherent visual security schema for TS. We need one schema for all these three areas in TS: contact list, message history, messaging window. Too much information and too much redundancy which leads to a cluttered and less usable interface. There is no "security at one glance". The icons under each message are too small. Visually impaired people might not even notice them. Those symbols don't increase with the chosen text size. Also, depending on the colour, the icons under each message are hard to read because the contrast is too low. Another issue with those icons is that there could be issues on smaller screens with less dpi. The lock symbol used on the contact list doesn't visualize the idea of three security levels well enough. Threema's indicator does so by telling the user that there are three levels and contrasting it with how many he already has achieved. I think this schema also presents an incentive to gain better security which the uni-coloured lock symbol doesn't. III. The alternative model I have used Threema's dots to implement the security indicator but I have also "designed" some other possible indicators (see below). Maybe it's not even possible to use Threema's dots due to legal reasons. This is only an example. Bear with me, I really don't know my way around a real graphics program so this is all done with MS Paint... ;) Contact list Messaging window Message history Short explanation of how this model works: First of: Threema doesn't use SMS, so TS has an enhanced model and more use cases. Level 1 (red): The user is communicating via SMS. It doesn't matter if the number of his contact is already in his contact list. As far as I know, SMS can be easily fabricated so it doesn't even matter if the user receives encrypted SMS, because the other party could be anybody, at least as long as there has been no verification of keys. So whether the user is communicationg via encrypted or unencrypted SMS, with the number in his address book or not, doesn't matter. The only possibility to communicate securely over SMS is to use TS with a verified contact, which would result in a green indicator. Level 2 (orange): This is for push messages that come from contacts in the usuer's address book which are not yet verified. Encryption is being used. EDIT: We should award SMS an orange indicator if there have been previous push messages and we already know that the key is connected to that number. In the case where a SMS reaches our phone from somebody unknown to us, this SMS will still have a red indicator. Level 3 (green): The user has verified the contact from his contact list and uses encryption. Discussion: Only one message colour for everything. Message colour doesn't resemble security any more, only the security indicator does. The message colour can be any colour we choose and it should be customizable in the future anyway. Though the colour should probably not be the green, orange or red of the security indicator so that people don't get confused. Also we need better contrast with the timestamp. The user can understand the security level with one glance at the security indicator. No locks, no verification badges and no transport symbols under the messages. No tiny symbols, that can't be ready by visually impaired people or won't be displayed correctly on lew-res screens. Colour-vision impaired people can still see which security level is being used. This leaves more room for what the user actually wants: communicating. I think we are too much in his face, constantly displaying something. Under each message there will only be a timestamp. I think there should be a warning message if a contact with two numbers (one of them isn't registered with TS) talks to the user and the security changes. Only switching to a red indicator probably doesn't cut it. Again, the indicator always tells you the security of your next message. If you want to know the security of your last messages, you will have to tap and hold on a message so that you can access message details. Not displaying transportation under each message might be unwise, because users who pay for SMS or Data depending on usage really want to know what TS is doing. I think the solution to this is asking the user at first start how TS should handle this. As far as I know this will be or already has been integrated into TS so we probably don't have to worry about it that much. This means either TS is not allowed to act in a way that would cost the user money or TS will ask the user what to do. The way of transportation will always be in sight, though, because the text in the message composing area will always display whether the next message will be a SMS or push message. The only thing that I would wish somebody would add is that I could allow TS to use SMS for 15min, a few hours or a day, but ask me again once this time is over. The paperlane doesn't have a lock anymore either. IV. Some ideas for security indicators This indicator needs to convey three levels of security and the user should always get the idea that more is better. Again, purely MS paint. This is taken from Google Chrome: This is the modified TS icon: Can anybody think of more? V. Conclusion Ok, this is the model I wanted to propose. Feedback is very welcome. It would also help a lot if somebody could just make new, more professional looking mockups of the screenshots.
Manager.title: Alternative model to visualize security in TS

It always says the textsecure-password is invalid. A workaround is to create a dummy key (123456789) import your encrypted backup and reboot the phone. After the successful import of the backup I¬¥ve noticed that my key has changed!!! Any of my contacts who had my key before the backup cannot decrypt my messages anymore. IMHO this needs a quick fix as it breaks all previously established communications with your contacts
Manager.title: Wrong encrypted message after restore

Manager.description: I had problems with connection to GCM and didn't recognize this. All conntects that sent messages to me, thought I got them and all works fine. It would be great, if there were a visualisation, that shows the status of the message. Maybe: sending, server received message, client (contect) received message, (optional) contect has read message. With such a status I have not to wait for an answer to a message that is never received by the other part.
Manager.title: receive acknowledgement for data messages

Manager.description: When changing the image of a group, basicly nothing happens. In the group editing activity, after selecting an image, it doesn't appear in the preview at the top left. After saving, an "Updated the group" message is generated, but the placeholder image is still there. Device: Nexus 4 with CyanogenMod 11 (KitKat)
Manager.title: Changing a group image doesn't work

Manager.description: As I had some issue with registering for push service I removed TextSecure and performed a fresh install. To save my account I exported an encrypted backup right before uninstalling. At re-importing the backup up file I was asked for the password of the backed up account as I had expected. On several attempts I got the message "Incorrect password" although I'm absolutely sure that the password was correct as I had entered it only some minutes ago. Unfortunately I cannot provide and debug log as I with the seemingly incorrect password I could not enter TextSecure and therefore had to reinstall it another time.
Manager.title: Import of previously exported encrypted messages fails due to wrong password

Manager.description: Messages are send via sms even when I have a valid key of my contact. the key exchange was successful; I can see the locker icon. Why are the messages not send through push?
Manager.title: Messages send via SMS

Manager.description: Ok, this is a bit weird: Today I noticed that I couldn't receive SMS any more. TS did not show them at all. No notification, not in the conversation, just not there. But since I have a Pebble smartwatch which shows incoming messages as well, I still got the notification on my watch. So it seems to have reached the phone, but did not get processed by TS. What happened? Titanium Backup set itself to be the default SMS app and I had no idea about that. And I still don't know why it did that because I haven't used it for days. The system SMS app handles this quite well by displaying a big warning dialog that TitaniumBackup is now the default messaging app, but TS kept quiet so I almost missed some important messages, I only received them because of my Pebble smartwatch. Now I know that TS will still work without SMS, so it should not display such an extreme warning message, but I think it would be nice to display it at least once, like "You just changed your default SMS app to be TitaniumBackup instead of TextSecure. Was this intentional or should TS be the default again? "It's alright" / "Make TS my default again"".
Manager.title: TextSecure should complain once after another app took SMS default away

Manager.description: In many instances, after receiving a new message notification (with correct icon/notification), Textsecure will not present any further notifications/icons in the status bar/section, although the "message received" sound plays correctly.
Manager.title: New Message Icon/Notifications Doesn't Appear After First Time

Manager.description: Hey, first of all thank you very much for your effort of developing such a great app! For my installation of TextSecure (2.0.5 on Android 4.3) it seems that the on/off-Switch to override system MMS settings does not work. Speaking for my particular case: if I enter the "MMS Preferences" Section the checkbox is checked. I may uncheck the box and return to the main menu. If I then go to "MMS Preferences" again, the checkbox is still checked (so it seems as if the change was not saved). In addition, I may not uncheck the checkbox again but reveice the following notification instead: "Manual MMS settings are required for your phone." If I return to the main menu AGAIN and go to the "MMS Preferences" Section again, I may uncheck the checkbox... still, it does not seem to be the case that my changes are saved. Sidenote: changing the MMSC URL, MMS Proxy Host and MMS Proxy Port seems to work - at least the values entered are still there once I re-enter the section. Thanks for your support - I hope my description is precise enough to be of help.
Manager.title: MMS Preferences not saved?

Another wessenger shows the number of unread messages instead which also is a fine feature

Manager.description: This is just a tiny problem, but I guess I can't open half a ticket, so here it goes: When searching for app, you get some suggestions and usually they are pretty spot on, so you don't even have to click search. When searching for TextSecure with a phone localized to German, you get the suggestion "TextSecure Privaten Messenger", which contains a typo. Manager.description: Long press on a message containing a link / phone number. Click "forward". Actual result - uses the text from the most recent message - not the one that I have selected. Expected result - use the message I have selected. Take this example: If I long press on "Join LOL Chat" and select "forward" TextSecure uses the message text from the last SMS ("DFS"). If I send a message saying "Alice's phone number is +447700900289" I am then unable to select that message for forwarding if there is another message sent or received after it. Hope that makes sense. I just want the message I long press to be the one which gets forwarded :-)
Manager.title: Bug - cannot forward message with phone numbers

Manager.description: So I was just replying to a straight SMS and the conversation window was full of messages. After hitting the "send" button, I was wondering whether I made a mistake because I couldn't see the message I just sent. Turns out that it was there, just hidden as I needed to scroll down to see it. I was a bit confusing. Would it be possible to automatically scroll down in this situation so the newly sent message shows up right away?
Manager.title: need to scroll conversation avec sending message

Manager.description: I am currently using TextSecure as my default SMS application but I wish I could divide my texts with sensitive data from my everyday texts. It is silly that I have to enter my secure password just to ask my friend "what's up?", and if I leave my password cached after that then my sensitive texts are just as vulnerable as any other. I suggest that we partition the texts into two parts. The normal texts can be sent and received without requiring any passphrase, just like any other SMS client. But one must enter the passphrase before security keys are exchanged. Then that part of the conversation gets encrypted and set apart, only visible when the passphrase is entered. Has something like this been suggested by anybody else? I couldn't find it.
Manager.title: [feature request] Unsecure partition

Manager.description: If a user (like me) has to re-install TS, restore some (old) backup or loses (part of) his data for some other reason, groups are messed up. The groups that he joined do not show up, and as far as I can see, there is currently no way to restore them. If someone tries to re-add me to the group, that does nothing. If someone writes something into the group, I see a message in an "unknown group", but cannot reply since my TS does not know the recipients. I think there should be some way to send the group data from one TS that still knows this information to the one that lost it. This is what I think could be done (let my buddy be called 'Bob'): I restore a backup, my group is gone. Bob sends something in that group. My TS sees that it's missing a group, and that Bob is most probably part of it. It sends a "please give me the group data" message to Bob. Bob's TS receives the message and checks that I am actually part of that group (so we don't leak group data to potential outsiders). It then sends a message with the whole group information to me. Also, there should be a way to do this manually from Bob's client. @moxie0 Since you're thinking about adding message types anyway (talking about delivery receipts), could this be done?
Manager.title: Add a way to restore group information

Manager.description: (This might be an Android bug, not a TS bug but I've only seen it with TS) I have the latest Play store release of TS installed and have it configured as my default SMS app. I had TS import the existing message store and everything shows up in TS just fine. The app also appears to send and receive both SMS and MMS just fine for me. However, I noticed that if I send an SMS outside of TS, the message isn't shown inside TS (I assume because it writes to the default message store and not TS's). Example: if I use Google Now and say 'ok google, text my wife' and send her a text through this mechanism, the message is sent and the little card that pops up saying it was sent shows TS as the default messaging app and opens TS when you click it but the message I just sent is not shown in TS. If I make Hangouts the default app again temporarily then I see the message no problem. I also have an app called Agent that detects when I'm driving and responds to incoming SMS with an SMS of its own saying that I'm driving and that I'll contact them later. These messages also do not show up in TS, but become visible when I switch back to Hangouts. It would appear that TS uses its own message store for all messages and does not synchronize with the default Android message store after the initial import. I seem to recall another issue here on GitHub where someone was asking for an unencrypted message store and an encrypted one and after thinking about it, I think if TS would use the default message store for "normal" unencrypted SMS/MMS then that would solve both that request and the issue present here. I understand that makes the codebase more difficult though as there are two code paths accessing two different message stores.. Is my assessment of why the messages are not shown in TS correct? Is this by design? Can we rectify this? I just know that if I'd convinced my wife to use TS as her default app and then she couldn't find a message that she sent she'd never trust TS and would uninstall it in a heartbeat. If we're going to 'sell' our friends on TS as a 'drop in replacement' for whatever messaging app they currently use, it has to show all messages sent/received by them.

Manager.description: I've been reading a lot of blog posts, reviews and user feedback about TS lately. At least in Europe many people really aren't comfortable with the fact that it's currently not possible to opt out of uploading all phone numbers to the TS server, myself included. This is also not something only the crypto nerds (I mean that in a very positive way!) complain about, but also many average users. Probably because it's one of the few things they really understand in the difficult landscape of privacy and security. And especially the uninformed are very anxious when they are asked to give all their contacts away. They wouldn't give their own number to any stranger on the streets and now they are supposed to give some strangers on the internet all of their friends numbers? The internet is the place where all the russian cybercriminals steal their money and evil smartphone apps are the way they get the TANs for the banking accounts, right? This argument is typically used in conjunction with something along the lines of "they are using US(=NSA) servers, oh no!". The second complaint may not be of any factual difference for the safety of the messages in a good crypto system, but that doesn't matter. It's repeated over and over again in blogs and reviews. Allowing users to opt-out is one of the easier things we can do to make privacy-aware users happy (and kill the US-server argument once and for all). I am aware of https://whispersystems.org/blog/contact-discovery/ and WhisperSystems#692 and would like to discuss the possibilities we have to increase the privacy of the TS contact discovery process. It appears that we are currently waiting for the silver bullet to be discovered, which probably won't happen any time soon. Below I listed the simplest solutions I could think of, which appear not to be overly complex to implement, but still give a good balance between effort and privacy. If you have other/better proposals, I'm all ears! Allow the user to opt-out and download the whole bloom filter Allow the user to opt-out and download a subset of the bloom filter based on the country code of the contacts. Realistically most people don't have contacts from more than 1-3 countries. It's a little less private and people with contacts from India, China and the US won't be much better off data volume wise, but most users will. Allow the user to opt-out and manually upgrade to push from the settings menu. This would be typically only used if the user knows the contact to be registered. This doesn't leak any information about unregistered users to the server and is basically what Threema does iirc. If we end up using 1. or 2., updates could be provided with tiny daily/hourly builds. This way the client only needs to know the global/server time + age of his database and can grab only the updates he's missing. If somebody needs to try push messages with the friend that just installed TS, because he told him about this great and secure app, we simply allow the user to do the manual upgrade from 3. The privacy-minded users will sacrifice the 40MB+ volume or do it when they are on wifi. I know dozens of people who downloaded gigabytes of OSM maps for OsmAnd. When other identifiers like emails will be allowed (WhisperSystems#1085) we are obviously in for another ride. The easiest solution would probably be WhisperSystems#1259 and allowing the user to enter the identifier manually if they aren't in the same location. Email addresses could be imported from the Android address book and upgraded via 3. tough. The preferred "privacy friendly" setting should be preselected if WhisperSystems#838 will be implemented. Thanks for taking the time to read this, I'll appreciate all input!
Manager.title: Improve privacy of contact discovery

Manager.description: I had several issues where recipients did NOT receive a message that was sent via PUSH. The reason being that they had data disabled or a privacy app was blocking features that TS needed or the sync with the TS servers did not work. My suggestion is to send an acknowledge back to the sender via the PUSH data channel. If TS does not see an acknowledge within 2 minutes, TS would try to resend the message via SMS (if the fallback is enabled) or notify the user that the message did not go through. Messaging should be reliable AND secure!

Manager.description: On many Android devices ADB debugging is enabled, allowing anyone with physical access to the device to make a full backup of apps and their files/settings. This can be disabled by setting android:allowBackup to false in the AndroidManifest.xml. It may not add much security for cases in which the user used a strong password to encrypt the TextSecure files. But consider the following scenario: unrooted smartphone Attacker has physical access for a short period of time no/weak/circumvented lockscreen password unknown but weak TextSecure encryption password. Even with physical access the user isn't allowed to read the /data/data folder and can only do online attacks against the TextSecure password. But if he/she is able to copy the whole TextSecure folder, the attacker can do offline attacks, more or less instantly breaking all simple passwords. There is also a nice talk, demonstrating this exact problem with password container apps like LastPass (interesting part minute ~13): http://blog.deepsec.net/?p=1740
Manager.title: Disable ADB backups for security reasons

Manager.description: tl;dr I propose to add a clean "registering a number by SMS to a different device" step. User Story: As a new user, when I want to register my telephone number B (SIM card for number B temporary inserted into my mobile phone B) on my tablet A (a device without phone or SMS capabilities) with the TextSecure PUSH server, I have to enter the mobile number B into the TextSecure registration form on tablet A start the registration progress (my device B immediately receives (a first) 6-digit verification code SMS) [X] wait for the 2 minute time-out on tablet A (because A cannot receive the registration SMS) press the button on A for registration via an automated telephone voice call which now triggers the registration process by voice call to device B (user must be capable to understand a female voice, English language. This is a second and different verification code. Problem: Not everyone is able to understand the quite quickly spoken verification code on the phone. Not everyone understands the English message Users cannot enter the first verification code: because there is no possibility (no input form) in the current registration workflow Users have to know to wait for the timeout in order to trigger the "sent me code by voice call" process Observation: I regard the second SMS by voice as superfluous (in the standard case), because I already obtained a verification code on my device B at step [X], when I would only be able to enter this code on device A. @moxie0 I think the verification workflow should be deliberately modified which solves many issues: before starting the verification process at the device A, after having entered the telephone number, two new second buttons are proposed automatic registration (this is the present workflow with the silent SMS to the device where you press the button, but you have to enter the telephone (BTW: Can't this be fetched from the Android automatically?) new button: "manual registration" (a verification code is sent via SMS to the device with the entered number) new button: "registration by voice call" (you receive an automated telephone call on the device with the entered number, and a six-digit verification code in English will be presented) Advantages of my proposal: lower workload on TS registration server (the second SMS is not necessary, this step after the 2-minute-timeout is obsolete in the case that the user can receive the verification code on their second device) time saving: the user does not have wait for the 2-minute timeout easier: no need to understand the English voice message verification code text message (SMS) could be i10n/i18n
Manager.title: [Registration] workflow improvement when registering using temporarily a second device: allow to use first verification code sent in first SMS

Manager.description: This is so bizarre I didn't know how to explain it properly in the title. Right now I have this text in the phone number field at the top of a thread in textsecure: "+1510xxxxxxx - Sms and and generally use the" (The xxxxxxx are actually 7 digits I just omitted them to preserve his privacy) This text should NOT be in a field meant for a telephone number! How did this happen? Well, I got a text from someone that went through my google voice number and was telling me they had a new number so I tried to copy just the number google puts there at the beginning of the text but It copied the whole text. I went into their address book entry and cleared their old number field to replace with the new data. When I pasted I noticed there was a bunch of text after the number so I cleared it all except the number then saved. I'm not sure if i saved the text by accident then edited it again or... maybe i saved the number that it was relayed to first then finally the proper number (not the google voice relay number)... it is a blur in my mind. When I went back into TextSecure instead of their number under their name I saw part of the text message in there. So bizarre. The google voice is ANOTHER google account pointing to my number, not the one that holds the address book on my phone. This number was copied from the text that is placed their automatically by google voice, he didnt add his number to the text himself. I don't know if that matters. I have deleted any thread from him in textsecure and started new ones. I have restarted my phone. I have deleted and created a new contact for this friend in my google address book, both on my phone and in a web browser which then syncs with my phone. I have deleted the whole thread from the other google voice account. I also tried renaming the contact in my address book... nope. Every time I get a new text from him or start a new thread to him this same bad string is in the phone number field under his name. No matter what I do it won't go away. It doesn't matter if I am connected to wifi or not (I have no data plan)... This makes me assume this data is stuck in a textsecure database somewhere. Why is the data in the contact phone number field not just retrieved from the address book on the phone at some regular intervals or at startup? Why is textsecure holding it forever in some table? The table must be associating a number to a number string... but why? Why not just use the actual number?? I notice that some contact number strings have a +1 in front of the number (USA international code) and some do not even though NO CONTACTS in my address book have this +1... so textsecure has a strange way of handling this data. How does it decide what to make this string? There are errors in this function. My suggestion is to retrieve this data from the phone address book and store it or maybe refresh it every time the password is entered or every week or something. I don't know the programming aspect... Thank you!

Manager.title: empty conversation list and error log

Manager.description: Hi, This is a question of usage, but you may turn it into a "documentation bug". I registered my cellphone # with TextSecure. I received a regular SMS from TextSecure (+1 412-212-8916) with a verification code. What do I do with it? I couldn't find on TextSecure a place to enter it. And I couldn't find a reference to verification code in the TextSecure documentation either. Thank you Gustavo F.
Manager.title: (Usage, doc) Verification code

Manager.description: In Germany we use without exception the 24h format. This is also configured in Android's localization settings. However, when opening the details of a message (long press -> message details) sent at, day 15:23, it comes up as "3:23 nachm." which makes absolutely no sense in German.
Manager.title: Use localized time format in message details

Manager.description: With the latest TextSecure my friend and I experience the following problem: When sending a message or when receiving a message the app is responding slowly/lagging. Example: Type a message Send message Right after sending the message type a new message => Keys are not processed, the app reacts slowly/lags Example: Type a message App receives a message => Keys are not processed, the app reacts slowly/lags After a few seconds everything is working smoothly again
Manager.title: High CPU load/App not responding when sending/receiving messages

Manager.description: Carrier: Sprint Phone: HTC Evo LTE Debug Info: http://hastebin.com/usonicabuf For example, I will have a group chat going on, as people post pictures to it I won't always get them and instead I'll have separate messages from each person that suggests I "Download" the message, when I do it fails and the MMS proxy settings for sprint are configured correctly I believe.
Manager.title: MMS Messages not downloaded and fail to download

Manager.description: Hi, I'm living in a country where you do not have a permanent internet connection. When you send a message to another TextSecure user while you are online, all further messages will be delivered via internet. If my internet connection drops, and my partner sends a message to me, I won't get it until I'm back online. I would request a feature on the senders phone (online), which checks with the server if the push message was delivered after a certain amount of time (e.g. 5 minutes). If it was not received by the receiver, a notification in the NotificationBar should pop up, which asks the sender if he/she wants to resend the message via SMS. I would love to implement this feature on my own, but before doing that I'd like to hear your comments! Regards, sternze
Manager.title: Feature Request: Resend message via SMS when receiver is offline

Manager.description: Humans are better at comparing images than comparing a long string. Currently, the latter is used in TextSecure, and it's very inconvenient. My proposal is to be inspired by Telegram, here is how Telegram users compare their shared key: Important: If we take that path, there is one problem which Telegram didn't resolve and we should - Users often compare their key visualizations over an insecure channel. The most common way is for them to take a screenshot of the key visualization and then send it via Telegram itself. This defeats the purpose of key visualizations, because Telegram should be considered an insecure channel until the keys are compared outside of it. The solution is just a simple message like: "Please compare your key visualizations in real life / over a secure channel, never compare your key visualization via TextSecure itself"
Manager.title: An alternative to the painful plaintext key comparison

Manager.description: I encountered this with a friend of mine who reflashed his phone and subsequently reregistered. I had an ongoing chat (using his old key) with him and noticed today that he had sent me a message yesterday and I had to accept the new key. But I didn't get notified about the new message in the notification bar I would expect Textsecure to generate notifications for all events including the key changed event, since this may lead to unnoticed messages, depending on usage pattern of course. If this behaviour is intentional, it would be great to know the rationale behind this. Anyways I want to thank you for your amazing work! Steps to reproduce: User A and User B both register with Textsecure Both Users exchange a couple of messages User B reregisters with Textsecure changing his key User B send User A a Message No notification is shown on User A's device Expected behaviour: User A should be notified of the incoming message with the new key
Manager.title: [Bug ?] Key changed events do not generate a notification

Manager.description: Hi, A friend and I are using TextSecure 2.0.8. I'm running Android 4.4.2 and he's running 4.3. We've exchanged dozen of encrypted messages in the past and everything worked fine. A few days ago, I sent him a message with an image and he replied. It worked as expected. Then I replied with a text message. It was sent as a regular SMS, the bubble color was green. (I was in a place with very bad 3G signal). Instead of receiving the message I sent him, he received a key icon, then a couple of hours later, what looks like encrypted text : He then sent me a message that appeared to be sent correctly from his side (blue bubble, nothing special), but appeared as "Bad encrypted message..." from my side. I replied him, the message appeared to have been sent correctly from my side (blue bubble, nothing special), but he received a "Bad encrypted message..." too. From this moment, all the messages we exchange are received as "Bad encrypted message...". Here are his logs and mine : https://gist.github.com/tbalthazar/7afe026443ee266cb4fb Please let me know if you need more info. Cheers, Thomas.
Manager.title: Bad encrypted message...

I am not aware of individual countries' rules and regulations; however, on their control list page ( http://www.wassenaar.org/controllists/index.html ) there's this document: http://www.wassenaar.org/controllists/2013/WA-LIST%20%2813%29%201/02%20-%20WA-LIST%20%2813%29%201%20-%20GTN%20and%20GSN.doc Controls do not apply to "technology" "in the public domain", to "basic scientific research" or to the minimum necessary information for patent applications. The document further elaborates: The Lists do not control "software" which is any of the following: 1. Generally available to the public by being: a. Sold from stock at retail selling points without restriction, by means of: 1. Over-the-counter transactions; 2. Mail order transactions; 3. Electronic transactions; or 4. Telephone call transactions; and
b. Designed for installation by the user without further substantial support by the supplier; Note Entry 1 of the General Software Note does not release "software" controlled by Category 5¬†‚Äë¬†Part¬†2 ("Information Security").
2. "In the public domain"; or
3. The minimum necessary "object code" for the installation, operation, maintenance (checking) or repair of those items whose export has been authorised. IANAL, but that sounds to me like TextSecure (and any other public domain/open source software project) ought to be exempt from cryptography export controls.

Manager.description: With reference to #1397 and after a discussion with @generalmanager I like to propose this small UX change during the registration step 2 (when the silent sms is used to register the device's number). Current situation: During Step 2, the registration currently waits for 2 minutes to receive the (first) registration SMS. This registration obviously fails in the case that the device (e.g. a tablet without SMS/MMS functions) is unable to receive SMS. If the user has a different device e.g. a smartphone with their SIM card and SMS/MMS enabled, they receive the first code on this device. After the timeout the first code is not valid any longer. The user can manually trigger the TS server to send a second six-digit-code via the Code-by-Voice-call function, and then enter the second code to finish the registration on their tablet. My suggestion (TOFU-compliant): In oder to comply with the trust-on-first-use (TOFU) principle and to avoid the abvove mentioned second registration cycle by voice (in the case of a tablet without SMS/MMS function) I suggest a code change to allow the entering of the six-digit-code already during the first cycle. I mean this: already during registration step 2 - while the device waits for 2 minutes to receive the first verification code in a silent SMS users should be able to enter the (first) code manually in case they are in possession of it because they received it on their other, SMS/MMS-enabled phone device. In my view this appears to be possible, and does not break the workflow, or introduces security threats. Advantages Less registration codes need to be sent, lowering the number of "registration failures during step 2" (when the device cannot receive SMS, but the SMS was sent to another device of the user) much easier and quicker registration for tablet users, because the timeout does not matter any more: user cann immediately enter the code in the first cycle (TOFU)
Manager.title: [Proposal for a registration improvement] When registering a tablet w/o SMS functions and using temporarily a second SMS enabled device: allow to manually enter the six-digit code during step 2

Manager.description: I have installed TextSecure for many of my friends recently, and have found on phones without a hard/soft menu button on the phone (which results in the vertical "..." on the top-right of most apps for replacement) do not have the unlocked padlock icon from which to initiate a key exchange. Once I established a key exchange from my phone which has a soft menu button, however, the locked padlock icon appears to discontinue the secure session. I have found this to be true on any android phone lacking the hard or soft menu buttons. If a specific example is required, the most recent phone I found this to be an issue on was the HTC Desire.
Manager.title: Phones without menu button do not display key exchange UI

Manager.description: I have a somehow special setup. As I use my mobile phone for business and private contacts I do not send my number when calling in general. So I have switched that off. For people that should see it's me calling them I have added the *31# GSM code in their phone number in the contacts so that my number is shown to them. (I do this because I have to take hotline calls from time to time and calling them back should not show my number). I now tried using TextSecure and found that when I type in a number that's in my contacts (and I type the number without the *31#) TextSecure automatically finds it and takes the number with the GSM code in front of it. Thus no SMS ever gets send because the taken number does not work on SMS. Would be great to have the GSM code filtered away, thus I could use the Contacts (which is also not possible with the standard SMS app with my setup) fully or at least just take the number I've typed into without looking it up further (this is how the standard app behaves). If there is any more information needed just let me know. kr Tom
Manager.title: SMS number always taken from contacts

Manager.description: one needs to touch the "phone" icon to get to the screen where one can add a new contact for a sender phone number (e.g. after one got a msg from that sender). this is bad because of 2 reasons: a) there is no connection between "i want to add this contact" and a "phone" icon (which usually means "call the person") b) one might not want to call the other person and therefore would not even touch the icon because you do not know if that immediately triggers an outgoing voice call (and thus you never find out that adding the contact is on the next screen)

Manager.description: I tried to follow the instructions on https://github.com/WhisperSystems/RedPhone/wiki/Configuring-Eclipse to setup my ADT for building TextSecure, but failed to use the ADT for building TextSecure. (Before you ask, yes using ./gradlew build does work.) If it is possible, can anyone perhaps create a new and updated Wiki page for TextSecure, i.e. how to configure and using ADT for building and debugging TextSecure?
Manager.title: How to configure Android Developer Tools (ADT) for TextSecure? (if this is possible)

Manager.description: How do you bill sms send and received from a user who don't uses text secure? My provider, Congster in Germany, has billed all sms send via text secure. I'm very surprised. Is this correct that these sms need to be payed? If yes this tool maybe secure but useless as the invidence in Germany is very very low. Looking forward for your answer. Best wishes, Ediz
Manager.title: sms just free for textsecure user?

Manager.description: After uninstalling TextSecure on one phone, the other phone still sends encrypted messages to it, which results in the phone receiving encrypted messages only. I'm not sure if there is a way of notifying key-exchanged partners about the uninstall but maybe this is of interest to the developers.
Manager.title: Autoclose Secure Sessions after Uninstall

Manager.title: can't send regular sms

Manager.description: I installed text secure based off a recommendation by a friend. I realized most of my contacts don't use this service so I uninstalled it. I now have two contacts that use text secure , and whenever they attempt to text me I get a unreadable message. Like this : HHJABBAOOIWHAHS3123191362ASAIHASBSD814612401246+KABQIWRB7579127. It is not a HUGE deal but its quite a hassle , for them and for me, to constantly remind them that they cant use text secure when messaging me. I assume that since I used to use TextSecure , that somehow it is still thinking that I can receive secure messagaes ? Even after uninstallation? ( Clarification : I can message Textsecure users , and they receive " Hey , how are you" , however when they respond all I receive is " KAKSHHAO+89HABIFUBIWOH+AISHBASFIUASF" , when in reality they said " I'm good how are you") I have done alot of research and I was told that sometimes it takes the developers some time to * unregister* phone numbers ; however it has been over 2 months. Any ideas or suggestions would be immensely helpful!
Manager.title: I keep receving coded texts , after uninstallation.

Manager.description: Hi, I installed TextSecure yesterday and came across an irregular behavior on the multitasking screen on my Nexus 4, running Android 4.2.2. Steps to reproduce: Open TextSecure plus two other random apps Go to the mutitasking screen Swipe one of the two random apps to the right. This is what happens: the app is removed from the list, the list stays open (expected behavior) Now swipe TextSecure to the right (one other app still has to be in the list) Result: TextSecure is removed from the list and the multitasking screen is closed immediately. Manager.description: I've installed TS, and until a few minutes ago I was unable to send any kind of PUSH message, it was defaulting to SMS, all the time. Admittedly there is only one contact in my list that I can use TS with. The app wasn't recognizing this contact as a TS user, it appeared in the list of TS users, but I could only send SMS (which failed right away because I disabled the SMS send function from the options). From what I can tell the problem is that when I exchanged my identity with this contact (over SMS) I didn't have the international prefix included in his number (he's from another country). This created an entry within my SMS database with that number. After installing TS and being unable to send PUSH messages I noticed this and added the international prefix. Nothing changed and I was still unable to send messages. Upon sending more messages I noticed that at the top of the window, next to the contact name there was still the old number without the prefix. At first I thought this was a display issue, but then I cleared the app's data, redid the initial setup but SKIPPED the SMS import procedure. This fixed the problem. Without any previous SMS to take the number from, the app took it from the contact list (or at least that's what I assume has happened) and of course took the right one. I can now send PUSH without any problem and at this point importing the SMS db worked fine and kept the correct number. I hope this help somebody and can be fixed. Cheers
Manager.title: Unable to send PUSH messages (with possible fix)

Manager.description: I am using TextSecure as my default app for text messages. However, there is a difference between TextSecure and other apps like my phones default or Hangouts: Using Hangouts or the default app of my phone, I can still access my messages via bluetooth. Third party apps like droidstats or airdroid are able to see the Messages and count them. Using TextSecure, droidstats does not "see" me sending messages and accessing my messages via Message Access Profile (Bluetooth) or Airdroid only yields messages of the time before I started using TextSecure. So I believe that TextSecure stores messages differently, though I don't know what the difference is and if it might be a design-decision (e.g. for security reasons). I see that those third-party apps would probably only work with unencrypted messages, but that would be fine for me. tl;dr: Is it possible to make messages sent and received by TextSecure available in the same way as "the default apps" do? I.e. that they are accessible via MAP or third-party apps, even though some of them might be encrypted. Disclaimer: I've not developed any app for android, so I have very little knowledge about how things work here and if there is a uniform way to store text messages.

Manager.description: While I think this is an important feature, some people were opposed to self-destructing messages. I would take it even further and do similar to Gliph, where anyone in a conversation can delete messages. A risk with Gliph is their effectively central control*, which the TextSecure team seems to have solved very elegantly. * Gliph is quite transparent, and have what they call Lockdown‚Ñ¢ Privacy Protection. Unfortunately, the fact remains they are in control of the infrastructure and could theoretically capture the passphrase next time you login. Meaning we have to trust them. Messages I send other people should disappear on my terms. The sender should have control over her messages, as she's the one providing the content after all. Without much insight into the project, I'd like to share my ideas. Let's hope they are of value. Scenarios to relate with Imagine two journalists discussing some political issue over TextSecure, and one of them loses track of their phone. Say this journalist didn't care immensely and neglected security in a way that his messages are now available to read for anyone in possession of his phone. If the journalist's friend could trigger the phone to delete sensitive messages‚Äîprovided the phone can reach the Internet‚Äîthey could rest more peacefully. In case you are not a top secret agent, something easier to relate to may be sending a message to the wrong person. If you realize you've sexted your family like around 10% in a poll by Recombu have you may want to have an undo button. (how do people accidentally do this?) Friends and collegues I care quite a bit about privacy and security, and although I've managed to make my friends care more than expected, there is a limit to what they'll endure. This suggestion would ease the pressure on them to control their habits. They won't use a very secure password if they have to enter it every time to read messages. Implementation complicatedness Putting this idea together into the product can get complicated. Should the recipient have the ability to disallow deletion? As he could already be in possession of the information, one could argue it may already be captured and that my idea gives a false sense of security to the sender. I think it's an issue with little impact to an otherwise very valuable feature. Anyway, if we let the recipient prevent such deletion, I would like the sender to be aware of that fact before submitting her message. If the recipient doesn't agree with letting the sender delete their messages or having them expire, he could disable it for future messages. The recipient may have the ability to disallow deletion/expiry for (specific or all) senders, but the sender must always be aware of which before sending. All this causes complexity and new UI considerations. It appears we do not want more of that. Everyone should easily understand their message's fate. Solution Let the sender delete it's own contribution to the conversation. Allow manual locking of messages as suggested in #283. That's a simple and in my opinion reasonable compromise resulting in an easy to understand model avoiding added complexity. Model Messages are owned by the sender, who can always delete them, but is also aware that removal from other devices (or human memories) cannot be guaranteed. User interface We have the following alternatives for deletion. Delete message or conversation... ...from current device only. ...from current device and send deletion notice for own messages to other parties. ...from current device and send deletion notice to other parties, regardless of sender. ...from other parties only, by sending a deletion notice. Potential problems How can messages be kept track of, and could this kind of ownership break the plausible deniability we currently enjoy? Would the ability to delete any message in a conversation solve that problem? Future considerations Let any party delete any message People should manage to handle this as a social issue, where if someone disrespects the wishes of message retention, they're reprimanded appropriately. TextSecure has no role in this. Expiring messages (requires UI modification) Perhaps auto-deletion after recipient specified time period suits better for TextSecure. Related issues #175, #176, #226, #283. I love that Signal was just released for iPhone!
Manager.title: Enable sender to delete own messages from all parties in the conversation

Manager.description: There is contact X and contact Y using TextSecure. X and Y used to send each other TextSecure messages but recently, things changed. X can still send TextSecure messages to Y. Y can receive them but is not given the possibility to send back TextSecure messages to X (the interface is offering secure SMS). The following is the story about how I fixed it and probably also contains the cause of the error: After searching for a while I noticed the following on Y's phone: When pressing "+" to start a new conversation, X was presented as TextSecure User with his phone number +49170854----. After clicking on the contact item of X, the conversation view opened and now on the top of the screen the was X name and below his phone number +490170854---- (note the additional 0 after the country code). Now I searched the phones local phone book for that number. It was quite a mess with the +49170-number being part of at least two contacts. And then I found the +490170-number, which was part of a Skype-contact and could not be edited. I asked X to delete the additional 0 from his Skype-account. Then I deleted the local Skype-contact entry in Y's phone book. After I cleared data and cache of TextSecure on X's device and on Y's device and re-registered both to the TextSecure push-service, everything worked again. Debug logs (a bit messy): X's phone: http://hastebin.com/iwipawemob Y's phone: http://hastebin.com/xakubapiro
Manager.title: Sending TextSecure messages between users works only in one direction under certain circumstances

Manager.description: Currently, when a new device is set up this disables any old ones, presumably to increase security. However, due to how this is handled in details this IMHO has pretty serious security implications: It makes it much easier to take over an account for prolonged periods. If someone gets access to the SIM for even just a second they can connect to that phone number. They then will receive messages directed to that number. The legitimate user will however not be warned of this in any way. He will get generic "sending failed" messages. Worse, if encrypted SMS fallback is enabled, he might not even notice anything is wrong. The recipient will get these messages, but they will not be decrypted, thus making it even easier for the attacker to appear legitimate. Even if the user figures out that someone took over his account, there is no obvious way to fix this. The only one I could figure out is clearing app data, however then he loses his private key and the people he communicates with have no reason to trust him over the attacker. It makes it impossible to securely and with little effort switch to a new device. Normally this would be done by distributing a hash of the new private key via the old trusted channel. However before linking the new device its private key/hash is not known (I have not tried if skipping linking a phone number at first would be possible and help), whereas once the linking is done the old device can't be used to distribute the new hashes.
Manager.title: Handling of new devices has security implications

Manager.description: Auto delete messages I'd like to request that feature again because many people already requested it in some issues, but there were some privacy concerns and it could be interesting to talk about them and maybe, after finding a good solution, to implement the feature! ;) So the idea is that messages automatically get deleted from the phones somehow. The suggestion that someone could delete the message from all phones remotely let some privacy concerns come up as you should have full control about which messages get deleted from your phone and which do not... Another idea (what I do appreciate) is the option to disable history like it's possible on hangouts (messages get deleted after some time automatically). For example messages get automatically deleted 24 hours after you read them. This could be an option in the conversation itself and you get the message "history turned off". Every participant should have the option to turn it off/on and it applies for all the participants. Like that there's no confusion and all people in the conversation should be happy with this solution and can turn it on/off like they want to do. The messages should of course have another color if history is turned off ;) I do like this feature, the only privacy concern could be that you can still capture screenshots of it, but maybe taking screenshots could generally be disabled in the app or you get a notification that someone took a screenshot (what should be possible somehow because it works on snapchat e.g., too, right?). Do you think this would be possible or do you have some other concerns? Is such a function too hard to implement or would you even like that feature? :)
Manager.title: Auto delete messages

Manager.description: Hello, I read on your blog post (https://whispersystems.org/blog/private-groups/) about some optimizations that could be done to group chats. Unfortunately I happen to spend a lot of time in places where the internet connection isn't so good, and this is often a problem. For example: I send a message to the 5 other members of the group; While the application is sending the message to the 3rd recipient, the 1st already has the message and answers back; Since the internet connection of the 1st is better than mine, the 4th and 5th recipients often get the 1st's message before mine -- that is, they see the message with the answer before the message with the question. Is anything being done to improve the speed of messages sent in group chats? It's not only slightly annoying, it's also causing many problems because it's not so easy to understand "who is answering which message" when messages come in the wrong order. Thank you
Manager.title: Group chat optimization

Manager.description: Hi, I have the stock Android 4.4 on a Motorola Moto G and my friend has Cyanogen Mod with TS as standard SMS app. We used it before on another phone, so now he has a different key. Mine however stayed the same. I can't tell my TS to switch his key. He also doesn't receive my messages (they're probably encrypted with the wrong key? Our numbers stayed the same). I do receive his though. I also receive messages with a key symbol and TS tells me that this might mean that someone's trying to intercept messages (I don't remember the exact message). Anyway, so I tried to end the secure session and it said session cancelled but I guess it didn't really cancel it because the "cancel secure session" didn't disappear. My friend send me his new key via QR-code by email and when I wanted to verify it, I got the message, that this is not the same key. Well, I knew that ...;) Is there a way to delete his key on my phone and start a new encrypted converation? Does it have something to do with me using the App from Google Play and him using the integrated CM app? Why can't I cancel the secure session? Shouldn't that always be possible? thanks!
Manager.title: Wrong key for contact and can't end secure session

Manager.description: Hey, I just reached for my blinking mobile (Nexus One, MIUI 2.3.23, Android 2.3.7) to read a TextSecure message. TS has been restarted (it asked for my passphrase) and after entering that, I see TS has lost all my messages but the newly received one (which is from a group now called Unnamed group). Unlike last time, I did not restart my phone, and instead tried to get some logging data out. I have no USB cable with me unfortunately. On a terminal (on device) as root I tried logcat | grep -E "TextSecure|whispersystems", but all I got was W/PartProvider( 2725): Got master secret: org.whispersystems.textsecure.crypto.MasterSecret@406b92a0 (... or so... beware, I typewrote that) So I guess the ringbuffer is already emptied, meh. Do you know of any way of getting my messages and pictures back? Can I supply you with more information so we can get to the cause of this? Losing the TS database happened to me once before; Last time, I put the blame on the failing battery and subsequent file system recovery. This time, it just happened like that. Of course I tell all my friends to keep backups, of course I have none. So maybe it's just Karma. Meh.
Manager.title: Lost all my conversations (again), how come?

Manager.title: Option to disable "Enable TextSecure messages? ..."

Manager.description: Currently TextSecure requires the verification SMS to be exactly Your TextSecure verification code: NNN[N]-NNN[N]. But some mobile carriers apparently append or prepend a certain text to the original SMS. The relevant portion of the verification code should accept them as well. In my particular case, Korean carriers have prepended [Sent from Web] to every SMS sent from non-mobile devices as a (poor) countermeasure to SMS spams, and TextSecure simply misses them. While this (dis)service is optional, it is opt-out and many Korean users are likely affected.
Manager.title: Some mobile carriers distort the verification SMS

Manager.description: When using TextSecure as SMS replacement app, there occurs an issue if one contact tries out TextSecure but then decides to go back to some other IM. Then TextSecure always pre-selects sending a secure push message - which will never arrive because the contact no longer uses TextSecure. So either one should be able to set the default communication channel for TextSecure contacts back to unsecure SMS, or at least TextSecure should remember the last communication channel per contact and default to that for the next message.
Manager.title: Set default communication channel per TextSecure contact

Manager.description: @moxie0 It seems that a per contact user setting storage may be a good idea for the future, as feature implementations such as per contact notification sounds continue to be implemented. Rather than see this fragmented across many different type specific databases it would seem creating a generic db for this task may be desirable. Would you agree? I have made some modifications that would require this type of storage as well for implementing a MRU (most recently used) transit type for messages instead of automatically defaulting to Push. But before creating yet another database in the factory I wanted get your opinion on the matter.
Manager.title: Per contact settings storage

Manager.description:
Dear TextSecure develop team, I am a honest user and a developer based on your source code. There are some problems while I am using the TextSecure app recently.
1. We can send the push message and sms message if we change another simcard which is not the same as the register number. But there will be some problems if we send a secure sms message, cause the simcard number is not the same as the register number, besides that, it will leads to anther secret key exchange, if we exchange it again the new received message or secure sms message seems crupt and can not be decrypt in our app. Reproduce steps: 1) register with number 180..... 2) remove the simcard and insert anther simcard 3) send a secure message to a friend in our contacts 4) send a sms messgae to the same number above 5) send a secure message to the same number above you can find some problems here...
2. Can not choose which simcard to send the sms message with a dural sim cards support phone, so my question is can we support the dual simcards phone both can send secure message?
I am waiting for your help, thanks!
Manager.title: Can we support the dual simcards phone both can send secure message?

Manager.title: show symbol when communication partner had read message

Manager.description: I'd love the ability to use Signal/TextSecure as my primary messaging app, but the lack of multi-device syncing is holding me back. At the same time, I know that most services that offer multi-device syncing (Hangouts, iMessage, etc) do so by storing your keys in the cloud, making your communications snoopable. So, I think it would be cool if I could get multi-device syncing from WhisperSystems apps, through directly transferring my secret key from one device to another, for example through NFC or WiFi direct. This might call for decoupling WhisperSystems IDs from PSTN phone numbers.
Manager.title: Feature request: Multi-device syncing without putting keys in the cloud

Manager.description: Currently, when send-via-data fails, e.g. because there is no internet connectivity, TextSecure will mark the message light green and offer to fallback to SMS ("tap to ..."). There is no way back to a light blue message / send-via-data, even if the internet connection comes back online. TextSecure should immediately and automatically retry to send-via-data, as soon as the internet connection is back online. This should be made visually obvious, e.g. by keeping the light blue background instead of switching to light green, or by adding a spinning circle icon.
Manager.title: Retry send-via-data before manual SMS fallback

Manager.title: Bad encrypted messages with latest v3 master

Manager.description: Hello, I have to report a weird bug. The other day I sent a message to a group chat. "N" receives the message just fine, and answers back. "A" responds to me in a private conversation (all this is happening via push), probably saying they couldn't read my message (?), but their message appears as "bad encrypted message". Annoyed by this problem that has always plagued me since the very day I installed TextSecure (it keeps happening every once in a while), I end the secure session with A, unregister from the push service and register again. Now A can read my messages and I can read theirs. Yesterday I posted another message to the same group. A could read it and respond, while N couldn't. However, when N writes me in a private chat between us alone, everything works fine (we read each other's messages). This "Bad encrypted message" has been affecting me -- and my friends -- ever since we installed the application. Is there a reason why it happens? Please find a fix, I feel embarrassed for recommending my friends this application and causing them all these troubles.
Manager.title: Bad encrypted message

Manager.description: If sending a push message failed due to a bad connnection the Toast message SmsReceiver_currently_unable_to_send_your_sms_message is shown. Ignoring if it is either SMS, MMS or Push. See MMSSender SMSSender It's kind of confusing if TS tells you that the SMS could not be sent if it was a push message...
Manager.title: Wrong Toast messages on sending error

Manager.description: I've had a problem communicating with one specific textsecure user for some time now. I currently have both our phones in front of me and its clear that her phone doesn't know my identity key. As many times as I click "End Secure Session" on both devices, nothing changes. What should we do? Also, is there a way to force your device to completely forget the keys of a TS user and start again as. If it were your first text with them? I feel like that would fix some problems I occasionally have.
Manager.title: Recipient has no identity key.

Manager.description: Hello, I have not found a way to send a SMS to multiple recipients without creating a group. That could be useful for some reasons. In my case, I don't send messages to one well defined group all the time, it is very usual that I send a message to a group +/- 2 or 3 recipients. And it is often for only one or two messages. Those are the reasons why I think that having a way to send SMS to multiple recipients without creating a group could be useful. Thanks Thorleif, PS: I apologize if anyone suggests it yet but I haven't found with keyword and I have not enough time to scroll every issues.
Manager.title: Send SMS to multiple recipients without creating a group

Manager.description: Currently the confirmation / return receipt UI shows two states: Receipt confirmed Absence of receipt confirmation This could be more useful. It isn't so great when the remote user is e.g. in a building with poor data coverage, has their phone off, etc. Currently I often have messages get through which are never confirmed, but definitely received ... eventually. One implementation wrinkle I can think of might be a choice between "confirm all received messages, eventually" versus "give up on confirmation after a timeout." Either way, I believe presenting information on the state of message confirmation, rather than the presence or absence, is valuable to the TextSecure user sending messages. These proposals are mutually exclusive. Proposal 1: Confirmed, Awaiting Confirmation, Gave Up For messages which have been confirmed, TextSecure MUST (and does) show a "confirmed" UI element. For messages which have been sent but not confirmed, TextSecure SHOULD show an "awaiting confirmation" UI element. My suggestion: perhaps a clock superimposed on an envelope. For messages on which confirmation has been given up (perhaps after an hour), TextSecure SHOULD show a "gave up confirmation" UI element. My suggestion: A question mark superimposed on an envelope. Proposal 2: Confirmed, Awaiting Confirmation, Confirmation Is Taking a Really Long Time but If The Message Is Received It Will Eventually Be Confirmed For messages which have been confirmed, TextSecure MUST (and does) show a "confirmed" UI element. For messages which have been sent but not confirmed, TextSecure SHOULD show an "awaiting confirmation" UI element. My suggestion: perhaps a clock superimposed on an envelope. For messages on which confirmation is taking a really long time (say, more than 1 hour), TextSecure SHOULD show a "waiting a long time for confirmation" UI element. My suggestion: either a clock + question mark / interrobang (‚ÄΩ), or just a question mark or interrobang superimposed on an envelope. If the recipient phone is turned on 3 weeks later and old messages still exist on the sender phone, they will be confirmed. For unconfirmed messages which are deleted, TextSecure SHOULD discard incoming confirmation acknowledgements. Proposal 2 should be subjected to threat analysis. (What if the recipient doesn't want their receipt of the messages confirmed after a while?) Proposal 1 seems easier to implement while still actively giving the user more understanding of the status of their message - either we're still awaiting confirmation for a reasonable time or we gave up after a reasonable time but the contact may or may not have received the message.
Manager.title: [UX] Confirmation / return receipt UI should show more useful state than it currently does

Manager.description: From an article on Android Police: "Google's final announcement [about Google Play Services 6.5] may actually have the greatest impact of all. With the latest release, the GMS library will be broken up into individual parts for each major set of APIs. This will finally alleviate the stress of including the full library, which weighs in at almost exactly 1 MB after it's compiled into an app. For example, an app that only requires push messaging will be able to do so while only increasing its footprint by about 75KB. While most users with current, high-end devices probably don't notice the burden, this is great for older and budget-oriented hardware. This change will also go a long way towards reducing memory usage and download size. Oh yeah, and this should cut a minute or two off of compile times. Hallelujah!"
Manager.title: Use Google Play Services 6.5 for reduced APK size and compile time

Manager.description: For about the last two days, I've been getting the notification "Permanent TextSecure communication failure!" with the text "TextSecure was unable to register with Google Play Services. Com". After "Com" I'm was sure there were more letters but they are cut off. I don't know how newer Android versions work, but on 2.3.7 the notifications don't scroll so only by reading through code can I find the text that says "Communication over the data channel has been disabled, please try re-registering from the TextSecure settings menu." Of course, the next problem I have is that I cannot find any "re-register" option in the settings menu. Again, reading code shows me that the RegistrationActivity intent is launched by enabling "Push messages", which is already enabled. So, I do that. And now, finally, I get a warning message. Google Play Services needs to be updated to use this. So there's the issue. I'm actually guessing that I didn't need to re-register, I probably just needed to update Google Play Services. Can't say for sure though, as I've already de-registered. Anyway, the original notification is thrown up by a failed call to GooglePlayServicesUtil.isGooglePlayServicesAvailable(context). Instead of just checking for "resullt != ConnectionResult.SUCCESS", TS could also check for the other possible return values and tell the user the actual reason behind the error.
Manager.title: "Permanent TextSecure communication failure!" on Android 2.3.7

Manager.description: I have experienced this issue several times in the last few days and was able to reproduce it. I have only experienced and verified this issue with messages containing pictures, text-only messages seem to work as expected (apart from not beeing resent automatically via push when internet connectivity comes back, but that's a different issue). System: Android 4.1 rooted Samsung stock ROM TS 2.3.2 TS settings: Push messages: enabled Receive all SMS: enabled Receive all MMS: enabled Allow outgoing SMS to: TextSecure users: enabled Ask before sending SMS: enabled Non-TextSecure users: enabled Witnessed behaviour: When trying to send a picture on a spotty connection, TextSecure fails to send it via push and asks to tap the message to fall back to MMS. I tap the message and click no when asked if it should fall back. The message then shows the red triangle with the matching text that the message could not be sent. I now select the message and go to details -> resend message. TextSecure does not show the "please tap message to fall back" dialog again, instead the message stays in the failed state with the red triangle. When the internet connection comes back, the message is sent via MMS Expected behaviour: If the internet connection is still not available TextSecure should ask for permission to fall back to MMS once again, as it does with text messages. To reproduce: disable wifi+mobile data follow the above procedure from step 2 to 5 enable wifi+mobile data again you might have to wait several minutes or select the message and choose resent instead Log: https://hastebin.com/ipogomogov.vhdl I have another log ready if needed, but I'd have to scrub this one first. I consider this a serious bug because it can lead to rather significant unexpected costs as MMS are rather expensive (at least in Europe) and even more expensive if you are roaming.
Manager.title: MMS are sent despite denied permission

Manager.description: Not sure if this is a regression of the latest release, but I just noticed this behaviour on my Samsung SIII (GT-I9300) and wife's GT-I9305, both with stock Android 4.3 - both with latest TextSecure. When looking at a contact's thread, long pressing on messages that include: a photo or a number that has been auto-recognized by Android (therefore underlined) ... does not work as expected: Such messages cannot be selected (they will not be highlighted), even though the "info", "delete", "copy" and "forward" buttons will show up. Performing any action on them (like copy or forward) makes it obvious (when pasting or sending the forwarded message) that a different message has actually been copied to the clipboard! Example: I long-press on msg number 10 in a thread, click the "copy" icon, then paste in the text input area and a different message (usually 11 or 14 ) is pasted! The same effect is seen with copy/paste, forward and message deletion. To test whether you're affected by this bug: Find a TextSecure message that meets the above criteria (has underlined numbers or a photo) Long-press to select it Tap the "copy" icon Long-press in the message composition area Tap "paste" If a different message (or nothing) is pasted, you're bitten by the bug.
Manager.title: Message selection is unreliable for non-plaitext messages

Manager.description: When reinstalling TextSecure or switching the SIM card to another phone, PUSH service registration often fails because the number is already registered. This forces the user to go to https://whispersystems.org/textsecure/unregister/ and unregister manually. Average users don't know that they have to unregister first. They even don't know the above mentioned page. And that GCM eventually notifies the server about unregistration seems unreliable due to the fact that many users really have trouble with this issue and are unable to proceed using TextSecure. (just wondering if similar steps are necessary when web sockets come in...) I propose to let the registration process check if the number is already registered and automatically perform the necessary steps to unregister and re-register the number. When I understand the unregister web page correctly, this is authenticated by receiving an SMS (or call). I think this is possible when using the same SIM card / phone number. This would greatly enhance the usability.
Manager.title: Make re-registration of same phone number more userfriendly
