Manager.description: I have searched through all issues and was wondering i couldn't find this issue neither open nor closed. The idea is to have a status message with text and/or emojis for yourself and group chats. The problem for this ER is to display the message, because at the moment there's no space for it. If we look at e.g.: Whatsapp, you can see the status in the chat overview and in a contacts view Currently you can see the last message in the chat overview. I would rather like to see the status message of a user there instead. So I think it would be a smaller problem to achieve this. To have a status message in the contacts view is a tougher job, because there is no contacts view yet. What we have now is the stock android contacts view you get, after clicking on the contacts avatar in the overview. So this would be an entirely new view. Maybe this should be a new issue also... An own contacts view would be a nice improvement, because we could add other little informations there. I think this little nice improvement would make it more fun to use TS.
Manager.title: Allow setting status message for yourself and group chats.

Manager.description: AFAICS, textsecure uses some Kex based on DH which is effectively anonymous. When I add a new contact, it immediately sells me the conversation as being secure, even when no fingerprint exchange or something like that has happened. This basically makes the whole app and idea of encryption useless as anyone could MitM and I wouldn't notice, which is made even worse by the fact that I cannot even mark such contacts which I've manually verified to be verified (as it's e.g. known from OTR). Actually I'd prefer an option that I can reject any contacts which I haven't verified.
Manager.title: no way to differ between authenticated / unauthenticated contacts

Manager.description: According to @liliakai (we spoke in the Freenode channel), TextSecure uses SMS delivery reports rather than issuing them itself. This allows a malicious service provider (or, depending on exactly how secure SMS is, anyone that happens to be nearby the recipient) to withhold|drop a message that was sent via SMS while issuing a successful delivery report, potentially resulting in heated debates over messages that never actually arrived. To prevent this, TextSecure should issue its own (signed) delivery reports.
Manager.title: Don't rely on SMS delivery reports

Manager.description: We are using a group chat with 9 members (A, B, C ... H, I). I'm running TextSecure 2.3.3. The following happens when I try to send a message inside our group: I do see the small tick underneath the message (no blue or green background) I receive a warning that there was an error while sending the message (green background, red triangle), the tick disappears I receive a message telling me that there are changed, but unknown identity information. I can tap on the message, the message is replaced with a key. Nevertheless, everyone in the group receives my message. The same problem exists for at least two more users (B and C), but interesteringly not for everyone. Another problem is that I don't receive any messages from user D, but everyone else does (including B and C). There are also some users who don't have any problems at all. There are no problems if I send a direct message to any of our group members. The messages are encrypted and sent (blue background), everything seems to be fine. You can find a complete log over here: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/9d4097ed0db6e0339d53
Manager.title: Groups are unusable

Manager.description: Several times now, I've sent a friend a message only to have them tell me out-of-band that they received it, but couldn't read it. All of these occasions happened when we didn't communicate for several days. I'm guessing that the undecryptable behaviour is intentional, due to Axolotl deleting unused message keys after a timeout, to prevent an attack where the adversary withholds ciphertext in the hope of recovering the recipient device later. If my diagnosis is correct, please add some sort of UI indication on the sending side that this may be taking place. Currently, the absence of "delivery failed" suggests to me they received it and decrypted it, when only the former is true and the latter is false.
Manager.title: Notify local user when remote user's Axolotl message keys are expected to have be deleted based on timeout

Manager.description: Hi, the scenario: B sends an image to A over encrypted channel. There is an error on transmission A cannot decrypt the message Textsecure interprets the message as plaintext (in the pane with all chats it is visible in preview as some base64-string) On opening of the chat Textsecure tries to render the multi-kilobyte "text" message Crash This is critical as A can not chat with B any more. The only hotfix so far seems that B sends 10-20 messages to A, so the corrupted message is not visible on opening the conversation, but only after scrolling. It is still impossible to scroll behind the corrupted message this way, so this is just a temporary hotfix. Suggested fix: all text messages with more than X characters are rendered only partially and have to be clicked on to be shown completely. This will allow for the corruped message to be rendered partially and removed by hand. (As a side effect this will allow for easier scrolling beyond long messages)
Manager.title: Error on transmission results in large message, crashing TextSecure.

Manager.description: The section on export controls in README.md is wrong. For one thing, ENC and TSU are two different Export Exceptions. The way it works for "publicly available encryption source code" is there is a section in the TSU exception that allows export providing that notification of the location of the source is sent to NSA and BIS using email.
Manager.title: Section on export controls in README.md is wrong

Manager.description: I know this is a huge feature request and my intention is to begin the discussion. I've just started using TextSecure as a secure replacement for Google Hangouts. I use Hangouts both on my Android phone and on the desktop, so that I can switch to a full size keyboard when I am at home or work. This is a great feature that I'd love to see implemented by a secure messaging system. My suspicion is that multiple clients acting as the same identity (and hence all being able to read the same chat history and send messages) is either impossible or very difficult to achieve in a client-side encryption model. Is this true? Do you have any intention to support such a feature in the short or long term?
Manager.title: Desktop client

Manager.description: Cyanogmod WhisperPush is currently holding my account hostage. It will not allow me to unregister and therefore I am not able to register with TextSecure. Manager.description: Currently message delivery is unreliable. It often happens that I send a message to someone, but do not get a message receipt (check-mark icon). Messages sent later get a receipt. When I talk to the person a few hours later, they tell me they did not receive the message. This issue is not limited to me sending, but also happens the other way around. It also happens for other people, as I have been told. It also happens for the message receipts themselves ‚Äì sometimes a message arrives on my phone, but the sender never receives the receipt. The CyanogenMod integrated WhisperPush service is not involved. The issue happens between stock Android users, as well as with CyanogenMod users. From reading other issues I understand that GCM does not offer reliable delivery. I wonder if the equivalent of XEP-0198 section 4 "Acks" could be implemented on top of it in TextSecure.
Manager.title: Message delivery unreliable

Of course (if possible) you should be able to disable this feature if you think it invades your privacy! What do you guys think?

Manager.description: Dear developers, first of all I would like to say thank you for your hard and great work! I am using TextSecure for nearly one year now - with my family, friends and in my circle of acquaintances. During Christmas time a lot of those guys got new phones or updated to the newest available Android versions, running now mostly Android KitKat. The problem such "normal" end-users nowadays face, is the missing Emoji-button within the version running on KitKat. Unfortunately not everyone knows how to install alternative keyboards or is willing to do so. And not every type of keyboard offers the functionality of "Emojis" (e.g. on Huawei Ascend P7). There are several reasons I somehow could understand those people. It's a pity - if such users switch back to commercial messenger apps because of this "problem". It would be great if you could add the Emoji-button once again in the KitKat-version, so we could spread TextSecure even wider. Thank you for your time and consideration. kaz4r
Manager.title: Emoji-Button

Manager.description: When a PUSH message fails to send (say because there's no internet connection), it's given a green background and a red triangle icon to the left hand side. The green background is exactly the same as when a message is sent (maybe unencrypted?) over SMS because PUSH was no longer available for that user (or maybe some other reason). Manager.description: With the latest strings added to the TextSecure project on Transifex there is no way for me to correctly translate them to my language (Slovenian). Transifex has native support for plurals but it seems it only works if the original entries are added correctly. This worked on other projects but it doesn't work with TextSecure. From the Transifex documentation: "Transifex has native support for plurals, as long as the format itself supports them. Formats that can deal with plurals are for instance Gettext and Android .xml files. When Transifex encounters a pluralized entry in the file, it will associate both plural forms together. This way, Transifex can present the translator with both forms in the editor. At the same time, Transifex knows how many plural forms each language has and asks the translator to fill in all of them. That is, the translator cannot save the entry, unless he fills in all plural forms in the specified language." http://docs.transifex.com/developer/formats/
Manager.title: Can't correctly translate plurals in TextSecure on Transifex

Manager.description: The Hebrew and Indonesian translation are not working. values-he should be renamed to values-iw and values-id should be renamed to values-in I didn't want to make a PR because I don't know how the transifex integration is working... From lint: ../../res/values-he: The locale folder "he" should be called "iw" instead; see the java.util.Locale documentation ../../res/values-id: The locale folder "id" should be called "in" instead; see the java.util.Locale documentation Priority: 6 / 10 Category: Correctness Severity: Warning Explanation: Wrong locale name. From the java.util.Locale documentation: "Note that Java uses several deprecated two-letter codes. The Hebrew ("he") language code is rewritten as "iw", Indonesian ("id") as "in", and Yiddish ("yi") as "ji". This rewriting happens even if you construct your own Locale object, not just for instances returned by the various lookup methods. Because of this, if you add your localized resources in for example values-he they will not be used, since the system will look for values-iw instead. To work around this, place your resources in a values folder using the deprecated language code instead. More info: http://developer.android.com/reference/java/util/Locale.html
Manager.title: Wrong locale names

Manager.description: I'm writing this in hope of you deciding to keep the MMS/SMS support. My personal experience of using the push messages has been poor. Too many times has my messages never arrived to the person I'm trying to contact. This problem has been catastrophic when the arrival of the message was critical. Even worse when it's a urgent message that needs quick response, this has occurred to me on several occasions; which in turn caused me some troubles (Multiple times)! Personally I can not describe me experience with regular SMS anywhere near as poor as the push messages. With regard to the poor experience with the push messages service and the severe limitations of the current plans; I do not believe your reasons warrant reason to remove support for MMS/SMS. I would rather have MMS/SMS only and drop the push messages. Worth mentioning: currently contacting friends who're out of the country renders TextSecure virtually useless because no one currently has the data plan enabled while roaming. Keeping it on MMS/SMS mode circumvents this problem. Regarding polling of new members; I don't see why the app still doesn't check for new contacts while using the MMS/SMS service, this can be worked around... Since I've had a poor experience with the push messages on several occasions; I've been using TextSecure as a MMS/SMS client which had support for OTR, I had it all working in one single app. If MMS/SMS is dropped from TextSecure; I'll likely discontinue my use of TextSecure.
Manager.title: Plead to reject the plans for dropping MMS/SMS support.

Manager.description: Ok folks, with todays update of TextSecure to version 2.7.1 the real disappointment happened: Only unencrypted conversations are still possible, we are forced to register! So that means: Phones of privacy-aware users that are very likely rooted and have no Google Play Services are being "set on fire" by just disabling the encryption of all conversations, not notifying the user that the whole encryption thingy has just vanished. The people (like me) who refuse to flash GApps for adding Google Play Services (because they know that with those services you enable Google to remotely monitor your phone) are just doomed in this case. @moxie0, I've always loved TextSecure and RedPhone, but this is just unacceptable for privacy-aware people like me. Manager.description: I have supported TextSecure since the beginning, version 1.0. I started using it because it was a way to encrypt SMS messages. Now, it is just another encrypted IM chat program, unable to do SMS, and its original point its lost. It should not be called TextSecure anymore... Call it "Signal for Android" or something and fork TextSecure at version 2.6... I do not have a data plan. I do not have google apps installed. I can not use my favorite app anymore. I was SO ANGRY today and also so sad because something i loved just died. Moxie, you are making a HUGE mistake. Some people don't want to use Gapps. Some people don't have a data plan. Some people travel through areas where they can't get data but the standard SMS channel is available. Some people don't want to use limited data when they can use their unlimited SMS plan. These people were just told to go fuck themselves. I feel offended, insulted, hurt. These people are probably either highly security-conscious users who don't trust google or people who just don't want a data plan... they are not the enemy, Moxie, they WERE loyal users of TextSecure. You could still develop the push system without taking away the SMS fallback system. There should at least be a fallback system. And for security, what protects us from man-in-the-middle attacks now? If keys can be reissued whenever what stops a man-in-the-middle from distorting the keys to trigger a new swap then capturing the new keys? I don't feel comfortable with the push system even if I could use it. THIS IS A TEXT MESSAGING APP, not a damn chat program. I DONT CARE IF THE TELCOS HAVE METADATA ON ME. Why do you think you can force me to care about that? I care much more about not having Gapps on my phone. It is a sad day... so sad.
Manager.title: TextSecure should be renamed and forked

Manager.description: Since version 2.7 or so, TextSecure has become very unreliable. Half the messages I should receive don't come through unless I deactivate/reactivate data. Whenever the user with a new identity sends a message to the group, users who didn't yet accept his new identity receive a "private chat notification" asking them to confirm his unknown identity or cancel. after confirming each "confirm identity" notification, the message which was supposed to be delivered to the group is delivered to the private chat instead of group chat. no idea about future messages, but i believe they would be delivered normally to the group after confirming the identity.
Manager.title: Messages sent to group delivered to private chat after the sender uses a new PreKey

Manager.description: I recently got a S5 and the keyboard has a textual-smiley-button (":-)", etc.) but the emoji button can only be reached by changing the "," button to the left of the spacebar, which is very inconvenient. Can this be controlled through TS?
Manager.title: Emoji-button really textual-smiley-button on Samsung S5, Android 5.0

I do not really like that and find it uncomfortable to read with those colors, especially with the current choice of the chat background color (WhisperSystems#2773). Could you please add an option to change the message bubble colors? Oh, and before you say "But we need those colors to indicate which kind of messaging channel is being used (Data/SMS) and to indicate if the messages are encrypted or not!" or something like that (WhisperSystems#945), let me say this: I don't think colors should be used for that. I think those things should rather be indicated via icons, not via message bubble colors. And I don't use TextSecure for SMS anyway (IMHO TextSecure should have removed the entire SMS support, both, encrypted as well as unencrypted). It would be much appreciated if you could add an option to change the message bubble colors. Regards

However, just today, she got group MMS messages from friends that were unable to be downloaded in her default MMS app. Upon investigation, opening TextSecure, I saw those messages downloaded in TextSecure even though it shouldn't have. It appears somehow TextSecure is pulling down MMS when it shouldn't. It wasn't all messages in the thread, which left some messages in the default MMS app and others inside TextSecure for some reason. Samsung Galaxy S3 CDMA, Android 4.4.2.

I don't know about the inner workings of TextSecure but is it possible, that TextSecure tries to resend the Message after some time has passed without a receipt? If so, then maybe the received messages should be checked by using some kind of unique ID so duplicates can be deleted automatically.

Manager.description: Hello, I've vouched for this feature a lot, so I'll just write it here as a feature request hoping someone would take it seriously. We're a group of activists in an oppressive regime, trying to establish an IM-type of secure medium to communicate our initiatives among each other. TextSecure has been, theoretically, the ideal medium for us for so long. Yet, we never used it because it requires Phone Numbers. Hashed or not, our problem with that is not a "trust" problem against the server, but the problem is that if one of us is searched/caught, there's absolutely zero plausible deniability for him to deny his immediate knowledge if the people he's communicating with. The oppressor can simply collect the phone numbers I have on my phone (after a good beating to make me unlock the app from its passphrase), and take down all of the group. We need the ability to use usernames (preferably also making an option to FORCE Tor before the app can download or upload ANYTHING). That way, if one is caught, he won't be (as much of) a danger to us all, as if he had all our phone numbers in the chat screen. He will be able to use his cover story to deny and save us and maybe even himself. Please consider that. We're struggling to get a secure medium for our communication. XMPP is not the way to go when it comes to Group Chat, and other Closed Source apps are just never the correct go-to app. This app is absolutely perfect, if only it allows us to completely get rid of phone numbers. Not just for people whom I don't have their phone numbers, but even for my contacts that are in my phone book. We need a way to not reference phone numbers in TextSecure AT ALL. Please make it happen. If I had what I could benefit you with, I'd gladly offer it, but unfortunately I'm not able to offer anything back to this great community of developers.
Manager.title: Username Support and Optional Phone Number Destruction

Manager.description: In the past i have been able to use TextSecure to encrypt my SMS without having be online at all times. Manager.description: Hello, I have not yet had the chance to use the internal TextSecure Emoji drawer (2f20bb8) myself, since TextSecure 2.10.x still seems to be in beta. But I now saw that you seem to be using the Google Emojis for the internal TextSecure Emoji drawer, or at least I assume that's what you are doing by looking at this: https://github.com/WhisperSystems/TextSecure/tree/master/assets There is an issue with this though. Signal-iOS of course is using the Apple Emojis. And they sometimes look very different from the Google Emojis. You can see a comparison between the Apple Emojis and the Google Emojis over there: http://www.explodedsoda.com/2013/07/ios-to-google-hangout-emoji-comparison.html As you can see, they sometimes look very different. So they can easily get lost in translation. There is an whole article about this issue, which describes the issue quite well, see the following article: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/27/emoji-meaning_n_5530638.html There are some alternative Emoji sets available though, which look more similar to the Apple Emoji set than the Google Emoji set does. And they even are open source. For example: There is the Twitter Emoji set called "Twemoji", see: https://blog.twitter.com/2014/open-sourcing-twitter-emoji-for-everyone https://github.com/twitter/twemoji The Twemoji set looks more similar to the Apple Emoji set, see the following comparison for example: http://mroth.github.io/emojicompare/ As you can see, the Twemoji set looks more similar to the Apple Emoji set than the Google Emoji set does. And there also is the "Emoji One" Emoji set, see: http://emojione.com/ https://github.com/Ranks/emojione The Emoji One Emoji set also looks more similar to the Apple Emoji set. Here is a big comparison chart where you can compare them (the chart even has the Twemoji set and the Google Emoji set): http://emoji.codes/family As you can see, the Twemoji set and the Emoji One set are both more similar to the Apple Emoji set than the Google Emoji set is. So, could you please use the Twemoji or Emoji One Emoji set or something similar in TextSecure-Android instead of using the Google Emoji set, to lessen the risk of them getting lost in translation (http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/06/27/emoji-meaning_n_5530638.html) when chatting with Signal-iOS users? It would be much appreciated. Regards
Manager.title: The Google Emoji set in TextSecure-Android sometimes differs noticeably from the Apple Emoji set in Signal-iOS and therefore might get lost in translation. Please use a more similar Emoji set, like the "Emoji One" Emoji set or the Twitter "Twemoji" Emoji set for example.

Manager.description: Hello, I am just submitting this issue just in case you will stay with the Google Emoji set, instead of changing the Emoji set as requested over there: WhisperSystems#2892 I assume the Emoji set used for the internal TextSecure Emoji drawer is the Google Emoji set residing over there: https://github.com/WhisperSystems/TextSecure/tree/master/assets The Google Emoji set there is an old version of the Google Emoji set though. The Google Emoji set recently has been updated, for more details see: http://blog.emojipedia.org/android-50-emoji-changelog and: http://blog.emojipedia.org/209-new-emoji-flags-available-today So, in case you should stay with the Google Emoji set, please update it to the latest version. Regards

There was no new key-generation process on the work phone required. Btw. the work phones firmware is also missing the google-services so a reauthorisation is not possible at all. When I talk about messaging this means transport via Internet. Steps to reproduce: Start conversation on my private phone. Outgoing messages from my private and my work phone always receipt successful. Incoming encrypted messages on my private phone are fine Incoming encrypted messages on my work phone are always corrupted (Bad encrypted message).
Manager.title: Bad encrypted message with two phones sharing the same number (Dual-SIM)

Manager.description: Hello, the Emoji drawer in TextSecure currently is using the Google "Noto Color Emoji" Emoji set. A lot of Android phones do not have the Google "Noto Color Emoji" Emoji set as their native system Emoji set though. Samsung uses their own Emoji set, LG uses their own Emoji set, HTC uses their own Emoji set and so on... You can see some of those Emoji sets over there: http://emoji.codes/family Unfortunately though, TextSecure does not replace the native system Emojis with the Google "Noto Color Emoji" Emojis, when the native system Emojis are not the Google "Noto Color Emoji" Emojis, like on Samsung, LG and HTC devices for example. So, when Samsung/LG/HTC users tap on one of the Google "Noto Color Emoji" Emojis in the TextSecure Emoji drawer, a Samsung/LG/HTC Emoji appears in the message input box and in the messages themselves, and not the Google "Noto Color Emoji" Emojis the user actually selected. So, could you please replace/overwrite the Emojis in the message input box and in the messages (and everywhere else where it is possible) with the Emojis that are being used in the Emoji drawer? Telegram for Android also has a built-in Emoji drawer and also has built-in Emojis. And Telegram for Android does replace/overwrite the Emojis in the message input box and in the messages (and everywhere else where it is possible) with the Emojis that are being used in the Emoji drawer. So it is possible to do it. Could you please fix this and do it like Telegram for Android is doing it? Regards
Manager.title: native system emoji overriding TextSecure-provided ones

Manager.description: Hello, the size of the Emojis in the TextSecure Emoji drawer scales with the system font size. So, if the system font size gets increased, the size of the Emojis in the TextSecure Emoji drawer also increases and vice versa. First of all I am asking me: Is that an intentional behaviour? Or is it a bug? Second: The size of the Emojis in the Emoji drawer actually is noticeably bigger than the height of the system font size. Or with other words: They do not match. If the the Emoji size scaling with the system font size is intentional, then shouldn't the size of the Emojis match the height of the system font size? Regards
Manager.title: emoji size not matching system font size

Manager.description: Hello, the Emoji drawer / keyboard toggle icon: https://github.com/WhisperSystems/TextSecure/blob/master/res/drawable-hdpi/ic_mood_grey600_24dp.png https://github.com/WhisperSystems/TextSecure/blob/master/res/drawable-hdpi/ic_mood_white_24dp.png https://github.com/WhisperSystems/TextSecure/blob/master/res/drawable-hdpi/ic_keyboard_grey600_24dp.png is (or are) smaller than the Emoji category icons in the Emoji drawer. It looks inconsistent. Also, the Emoji toggle icon (the smiley): https://github.com/WhisperSystems/TextSecure/blob/master/res/drawable-hdpi/ic_mood_grey600_24dp.png https://github.com/WhisperSystems/TextSecure/blob/master/res/drawable-hdpi/ic_mood_white_24dp.png is a different smiley than the smiley icon which is being used for the Emoji people category icon in the Emoji drawer (the smiley between the clock and the flower). That also looks inconsistent. In Telegram for Android, the Emoji drawer / keyboard toggle icon has the same size as the Emoji category icons in the Emoji drawer. And the Emoji drawer toggle icon in Telegram for Android uses the same smiley that is being used for the Emoji people category icon in the Emoji drawer (the smiley between the clock and the flower). Which looks and feels more consistent. So, could you please increase the size of the Emoji drawer / keyboard toggle icon in TextSecure, to make it match the size of the Emoji category icons in the Emoji drawer? And could you please replace the Emoji drawer toggle smiley with the same smiley that is being used for the Emoji people category icon in the Emoji drawer (the smiley between the clock and the flower)? Regards
Manager.title: Emoji drawer toggle icon is smaller than Emoji category icons in Emoji drawer and it's smiley does not match the smiley of the Emoji people category icon.

Manager.description: Hi, I've always wondered why this is, but just figured it may be some sort of bug. Like 80% of the time, the messages I send get the delivery receipt symbol (the check mark) "way" before they turn blue (meaning they have been sent). Basically I send a message, it is shown as pending, it gets the delivery check mark, and then it is shown as sent. And this happens all the time, way more than just half the time. I thought messages turned blue after they'd reached the server, and got the check mark once they'd been delivered. But how is it possible that going from my phone to the recipient's phone and back takes less than going from my phone to the server and back? Sometimes I get the delivery receipt several seconds before the message is marked as sent. Is this some problem with the server being slower at some tasks than others, or is it some problem with the client? Thank you
Manager.title: TextSecure marks messages as delivered before they are even sent (?)

Manager.description: I have read some closed/locked issues on this matter already, but I just want to add an extra push. There was argument that TextSecure is to be a secure messaging facility, and fallback to insecure communication is unacceptable. I want to argue that this position is unreasonable, and undermines the effort to get the general public onto secure platforms. The general public has practically zero concern about this; but I do. If text secure refuses to fallback to SMS, then nobody I want to communicate will install the app. The inconvenience of not being able to communicate when out of 3G range (I'm in Australia, we barely have internet in this country), or have exhausted your monthly data allowance (again, I'm in Australia), is more than anyone should have to tolerate. There is only one reasonable solution to this as I see it: TextSecure should attempt to send a message securely. If it can't, a popup informs the user it failed to send, and the user has an option to retry later, or send insecurely (via SMS) immediately. There should also be a "remember my choice" checkbox, and an option in the settings. I have people refusing to install, and uninstalling the app. TextSecure is the only decent, otherwise user-friendly, secure messaging app I have managed to find. All others are borked in various critical ways. Please consider the importance of this app actually being used by an exponential explosion of users; 99% of whom don't give a damn whether it's secure, but must be convinced to use it by the 1% of people who do.
Manager.title: SMS fallback

Manager.description: TextSecure should attempt to send a message securely. If it can't, a popup informs the user it failed to send, and the user has an option to retry later, or send insecurely (via SMS) immediately. There should also be a "remember my choice" checkbox, and an option in the settings.
Manager.title: SMS fallback

Manager.description: We live in times where even the fact that somebody's using encryption raises suspicions. In my eyes a first suspicious sign would be a telephone number which is stored in a database of a messenger like TextSecure. Gathering those is a low hanging fruit because we all know that the structure of telephone numbers is very deterministic and entropy of those is additionally reduced by TextSecure. Another reason is that some people just don't like that everyone who has ones telephone number knows that TextSecure is used. I suggest to give more control over that. The easiest solution I can imagine is that there's a "cloak" mode: Alice uses TextSecure. However, she doesn't want that Mallory knows that Alice is using that App so Alice activates the cloak mode. In this mode, every time Mallory searches for intersections on the server Alices token is ignored. To get in touch with a cloaked user, I suggest the following approach: Bob wants to contact Alice. Alice is still in cloaking mode. Bob can select Alice from his phone contacts for a contact request. Alice receives this request. If she acknowledges, Bob get notified that Alice is available. If Alice ignores the request, nothing happens. Other, less convenient solutions I thought of: It's not possible that Mallory can see Alice in the intersection request if Alice doesn't have Mallory in her contact list. (Here the server whould have to know and store contact link information which is bad.) There's a kind of challenge-response technique via another channel than TextSecure which allows Bob to add Alice to the contacts. (More complicated and requires a second channel) What do you think? Greetings, Noir
Manager.title: Everyone who has my phone number can figure out that I use textsecure

Manager.description: If you leave a group the thread is not deleted but you lose the ability to type in the input box and send messages. [1] I assume this is the expected behavior as you might still want to view past messages after leaving. However if everyone else leaves the group you can still do everything: type text, add attachments and send messages. This makes no sense since there are no recipients anymore. The thread should be "locked" as in the case above where you are the one who leaves. Adding more people (updating group) should "unlock" the conversation again. There are many issues about groups but could not find anything about this case. TS 2.12.0, stock Android 5.1 Edit: Here's a debug log after the following steps: Open TS first time after boot Go to a group All the other people leave the group (in this debug log all the other people = one person) I send a message to the empty group ([1] You can still type using the TS emoji drawer. Also you can add attachments. But it might be best to add this as a separate issue.)
Manager.title: You can still send messages when you are left alone in a group

Manager.description: When typing a message longer than a single line, TextSecure allows the user to scroll the input box left and right in order to see the whole input. It would be nice if instead of this scrolling function the box simply gained another line as the length of the message increased. This would allow the user to always see the entire message without scrolling. While this would take up slightly more vertical space, this would be especially useful when reviewing the message before sending (say, to make sure nothing was autocorrected incorrectly). Plus, TextSecure already increases the input area, though only to show the number of characters when they go past the 160 character mark. Thanks.

Manager.description: You know the little pulsing bar that appears when writing something in a text box? (I'm sure i thas a name but I can't think of a better description right now). Since 2.14.1 (probably 2.14) it has disappeared from textsecure. This obviously makes it hard and uncomfortable to write messages.. I like textsecure, and I appreciate the effort you're putting into it, really. But do you even test the app before releasing updates? Missing commas that screw the phones and make us lose messages, huge usability problems that would've taken 10 seconds to notice... I mean... of course it's human to forget a comma or introduce bugs, we all know it. The problem is that testing should be considered fundamental, even when you have beta testers. Beta testers are supposed to find smaller problems, not sacrifice their product for the sake of bugs. That's what the developers should be doing. Apologies if it sounds rude, and thanks again.
Manager.title: Cursor not shown when typing a message

Manager.description: This is something I encountered while trying to reproduce #3134 of which I cut 'n' pasted my comments here because the issue appears to be separate. Sometimes when I open a conversation the cursor is missing. This happens on average 5% of the time. The cursor comes back when you tap the input box though. I speculate this issue was introduced in 2.14(.1) but I'm not sure if I would have noticed anything without #3134. Here are some tests I ran while trying to pin it down: for each conversation in the main conversation list repeat (30, 50 or 100 times) open the conversation count if cursor shows or not tap Android's back button to go back to main conversation list Nexus 4, Android 5.1, TS 2.14.1 1st priv. conv. 1: 0/50 (ok after 50 tries nothing, i give up) 2nd priv. conv. 2: 3/30 3rd priv. conv. 3: 5/30 4th priv. conv. 4: 2/30 1st group conv. 1: 1/30 5th priv. conv. 5: 2/30 6th priv. conv. 6: 0/50 Result: in 13/250 cases I got a missing cursor. The conversations that got 0% do not really differ from the others. Huawei U8880, Android 4.0.4, TS 2.14.1 1st priv. conv. 1: 0/100 Does not seem to happen on 4.0.4. But I had just one conversation. Here's a debug log from Lollipop after: rebooting phone opening TS switching between the conversation list and a specific conversation until the cursor disappeared (took 16 tries) I realize this is a "new version of TextSecure makes my phone run 0.4 Fahrenheit colder than before and it's affecting my testicle balance when I keep my phone in my pocket" type of an issue but I'm doing this mostly for documentation. Maybe this has some relevance to another more important case in the future. I think I'm gonna unsub myself as soon as I hit that Submit button.
Manager.title: Cursor occasionally missing when opening a conversation

Manager.description: In a group message (at least unsecured, not sure if true in secure chats), the "Group members" view shows a list of contacts and unknown numbers involved in the message. Each entry is clickable, and closes the view. I would think the expected behavior on unknown numbers should be to add a number to contacts, similar to tapping their avatar in a message. Assuming that person ever actually participates in the thread, it's a somewhat moot point, as you'll be able to tap the avatar, but I've had situations where a group member doesn't participate, so the shortcut of adding a contact isn't available. For existing contacts, I would think opening their contact information would be a good default, which would be consistent with using the same behavior as clicking their avatars in the conversation view. Device: Samsung Galaxy S5, Android 5.0 (stock rom), TextSecure 2.13.0 App state: Push registered, SMS enabled incoming/outgoing
Manager.title: Feature: Add contact from number in "Group members" view

Manager.description: I received an SMS from my boss earlier (he's an iPhone user, using the default iOS SMS client) and, for some reason, TextSecure opened from the notification but crashed afterwards, hanging on a black screen after entering my passphrase and prompting Android to ask me if I wanted to Report/Wait/Close. I hit the app switcher button and dismissed TextSecure and tried the notification again but just got the black screen, so told Android to report the crash. I dismissed TextSecure via the app switcher again and opened TextSecure from the app shortcut and it let me in ok, but the text message now reads, in italics: Received a message encrypted using an old version of TextSecure that is no longer supported. Please ask the sender to upgrade to the most recent version and resend the message. except, as I mentioned, my boss isn't using TextSecure; he's using the default iOS SMS client. After whining about it on Twitter, @WhisperSystems replied asking me to open an issue with a debug log. So here I am, with a debug log at https://gist.github.com/anonymous/9111ffde3f88317b203b üòé

Manager.description: Hi everyone, after a good time using TextSecure I am starting to experience a really crippling bug that has many different outcomes: I am missing a certain number of messages (were sent to me but never received); Those I do receive are hardly ever pushed with a notification. Manager.title: S6 Edge - Quick Reply not working when Textsecure is default Message App

Manager.description: Hello, I think it would be really nice if a textsecure message has not been received it auto-retries using the unsecured SMS (ofcourse, only optional, disabled by defalt). This is useful in many situations like roaming or even when you want to save battery and disable push or mobile networking completely (and someone else tries to reach you). So what I propose is to add an option to notify the user when his textsecure message has not been recieved for X minutes and/or add an option to automatically send the same text via SMS to make sure it reaches the other one ‚Äì ditching the security for a moment when other things are more important. For "normal" textsecure users this can be a rather frequent annoyance. EDIT: If possible, maybe one should delete the secured TextSecure message if the auto-falback SMS has been sent to avoid double-sending
Manager.title: SMS as auto-fallback

Manager.description: I received an SMS from Google Calendar's SMS notification short-code (48368) that TextSecure believes was encrypted with an out of date version of TextSecure. I do not believe that Google uses TextSecure's encryption (correct me if I'm wrong), thus I'm lead to believe that TextSecure is incorrect in it's evaluation that the message was encrypted. I am unable to retrieve the original ("encrypted") text. TextSecure simply displays the "error" text: Received a message encrypted using an old version of TextSecure that is no longer supported. Please as the sender to upgrade to the most recent version and resend the message. Sent May 15th, 2015 02:10:02 PM EDT. I believe I was up-to-date at that time. My current version of TextSecure is 2.14.5 on Android 5.1. I have since received another message from 48368 which was not evaluated as encrypted and displayed as a normal unencrypted SMS. Is there any further information I can provide to help debug the issue? Is there anyway to get the original ("raw") SMS message from under that error?
Manager.title: Received a message that may have been incorrectly identified as encrypted with an old version of TextSecure.

Manager.description: As far as I know, there's no great way for a list adapter to notify each list item that it needs to be recycled in the event that the activity is being paused/stopped/destroyed. Because of this, there's context leak around our Recipient listener logic. Seems like we should either 1) find a consistent way for RecyclerView/ListView adapters to listen to lifecycle events and report them up to their bound list items, or 2) make all our RecipientListeners only hold a weak reference to the context.
Manager.title: memory leaks with list items listening to recipient changes

Manager.description: I have weird problems with one of my friends. It just won't encrypt my messages anymore even though it worked before (like a couple of weeks before). She says however that the messages are shown in blue to her. But for me they are green and the lock is open. The info says that I am using insecure messages. Manager.description: Hello, this is a follow up to: WhisperSystems#957 Delivery receipts are implemented now. But read receipts are still missing. Could you please add an optional read receipt feature (turned on by default)? Those users who wouldn't like it could simply disable it. Regards
Manager.title: Please add optional read receipt feature

Manager.description: Hello, could you please add an optional online/offline/last seen status feature? Other popular messengers like Telegram for Android and WhatsApp for Android do have that feature and it can be quite useful. Those users who wouldn't like it could simply disable it. Telegram has a rather nice way of handling this, see: https://telegram.org/blog/privacy-revolution So, could you please add such a feature? Regards
Manager.title: Please add optional online/offline/last seen status feature

Manager.description: When I look at my sms/TS message info for received messages they always have the received time before the sent time. So received time could be 8:01:25 and sent time would be 8:01:30, for example. This is with users of any network and timezone as far as I can tell. Did they happen to get switched accidentally in the code? The difference in time is just a few seconds which would look right to me. Running 2.16.3 on galaxy s4 stock Verizon 5.0.1.
Manager.title: Received messages info always has received timestamp before sent timestamp

Manager.description: On the textSecure panel showing the list of threads, each of them has a field showing the time elapsed since the last message. typically I read something like "11 mins". I wonder what the s after min stands for. Unit for minute is min, and units do not take plural form. Unfortunately I must say that this trend of putting plural mark to units is more and more common in the US, and it appears that it is getting more common in other countries as well. Spreading that nonsense is definitely not good so I suggest that the "plural unit issue" be taken care of as soon as possible. Check also for the hour, I am pretty sure that soon some "hrs" will show up. "h" would actually be the best, while "hr" being also accepted. Thank you
Manager.title: units

Manager.description: Since a few days I experience a strange behaviour of TextSecure 2.14.5 on my OnePlus One with Android 5.0. I'm chatting with someone and the messages I send definitely get delivered: I see the checkmark under the message and my dialog partner reacts/answers on what I have written. Then, after some time (half a minute to several minutes) the checkmark disappears, I see a red exclamation mark left of the message and below it reads Nicht zugestellt (German for Not delivered). When I open the message details it offers to re-send the message, but this only removed the error message and does not bring back the checkmark. Do you have any idea what's going wrong here?
Manager.title: False delivery failure messages

Manager.description: Hi. Bear with me here. This could be a problem with Cyanogen, or may be more appropriate for the support form. Feel free to close if either of these are the case. Android 4.2.2/Samsung SGH-T399/TextSecure 2.16.4 Debug log: https://gist.github.com/35c5e8f3086090a31234 I've mysteriously been registered to Cyanogen's whisperpush server for awhile now (I've never installed cyanogenmod on my device), and finally got around to unregistering myself. Previously, while I was registered, my friend who uses cyanogenmod tried to send me multiple encrypted messages, which would silently fail. After unregistering from Cyanogen's servers today, I downloaded TextSecure, and successfully registered with my phone number. However, when my friend with cyanogenmod and I tried sending encrypted messages to each other, we received "bad encrypted message" for each message we sent. He tried disabling encryption on his end (in which case i could only send him sms messages) and re-enabling it, but we still got "bad encrypted message" errors. Maybe some sort of problem with key exchanges failing when I was registered to cyanogen servers?
Manager.title: 1. Unregister from Cyanogen 2. Download TS 3. "Bad Encrypted Message"

Manager.description: Those who have used Google's "Messenger" application for Android in its more recent iterations may have noticed a new feature for attachments. Clicking the "paperclip" for Attachments , besides the usual options to attach a file, gives the user the option a number of "Quick, in-app, in-line" media capture options. For instance, choosing Picture (or alternately, Video) allows the user to capture the picture or video right from Messenger (a camera window is opened below the text entry box ) which is then added to the message to form the outgoing MMS. Likewise, if the user chooses the Audio tab there is a "Microphone button" and instructions to "press and hold to record". Doing so allows the user to speak a message which is then encoded as an audio file and added to the outgoing MMS. From what I can tell, TextSecure lacks these options. While a user can send a picture, video, or audio file that has already been saved elsewhere, I believe it would benefit TextSecure to enable these "Quick Capture" options, both for traditional SMS/MMS and Secure(Data) messaging. Many users find these options alluring (particularly the audio quick capture, which allows the sending of a short audio message that can be played by the recipient at their leisure) and TextSecure supporting these features would mean users who enjoy them currently on other platforms could switch and enjoy better privacy/security without having to lose said features Please let me know if this seems feasible. Thank you.
Manager.title: Attachments - "Quick Capture" audio/video recording and playback (Google's "Messenger" Android app style)?

Manager.description: Over the past week I've experienced a very strange failure mode. Me and person P were exhanging unsecured text messages. I was using TextSecure (push registered), while P was using a stock messaging app. At some point, TextSecure on my phone started thinking that P was registered with TextSecure, and switched to sending encrypted messages. I sent a few encrypted messages to P, which P never received. Upon learning that P wasn't receiving my messages, I tried ending the secure session with P on my phone. This had no effect: TextSecure still insisted on sending encrypted messages. I tried de-registering my phone and then registering it again, but that didn't help. Ultimately the only way to reach P was to de-register my phone and keep push disabled :( The most pressing issue is: Why did TextSecure think P was registered? P never installed TextSecure or Signal, and did not change their phone number, or anything like that. The secondary issue is: Why did TextSecure not allow me to send plain SMS, even after I selected "end secure session"? I looked at the log, and the only potentially relevant line I could find was this: W/Directory(22806): Adding active token: +*********xx, 47+CqoNE/Fv5gw (where xx is the last 2 digits of P's phone number, so I know the line corresponds to their account.) (PS. Is the debug log designed to be safe for posting in public, or is there a document describing which fields should be censored?) Version info for my device: Device : LGE Nexus 4 (occam) Android : 5.1.1 (1836172, LMY47V) Memory : 33M (0.13% used, 192M max) Memclass: 192 OS Host : wpiw7.hot.corp.google.com App : TextSecure 2.16.4
Manager.title: TextSecure incorrectly thinks recipient is registered

Manager.description: Me and my friends all completely despise the Google emojis. I don't really know why, but the fact still remains that we do. With that said, I think a lot of people would be happy to see alternatives. Twitter's emojis are open source and look quite nice. Of course I would prefer Apple's, but those aren't open source at all so that might be a problem. I don't really see how WhatsApp could get away with using them though. With Signal for Iphone and Signal soon coming to Android, I think it's quite important that both people see the same thing. That's the way Telegram does it, and it makes sure both people see the exact same emojis. Some Apple/Google emojis are so different that it's not even funny. Yeah, I know Samsung for example has their own emojis, but that doesn't exactly make things easier. Is this being worked on? Is it even being considered? I even tried using Emoji Switcher to get Apple's emojis, but it just isn't working.
Manager.title: Alternatives to Google's emojis

Manager.description: I've tried over and over and cannot register my phone for TextSecure. I live in a remote rural area and cannot get decent phone reception at the same time that I have a wifi connection. If I drive to a spot to receive the SMS then I lose the wifi connection. If I try to do Voice Verify then it says no network - presumably meaning no wifi connection. So it's impossible to register here. I almost got it once by driving out to get reception but the short time limit of 2 minutes cut off before the SMS that came in moments later. I don't understand why you have to make it so difficult to register the phone, or even why a secure messaging app needs to have my phone number registered in the first place. Is this some hidden tracking agenda - why need the phone number for text messaging. But my real point here is to let you know that registration is broken for people like me in rural areas. It seems the only way for me to do this is to wait for some day when I'm at some cafe with free wifi and decent phone reception both together. Can this not be made less onerous?
Manager.title: Register time too short, cannot register without both wifi and phone network

Manager.description: Hi! I am am wondering why there is yet not an update on the still missing group SMS feature in Textsecure.The original issue concerning this question, issue #413, has already been opend in 2013 and now, in mid 2015, there is still no information, when the feature will be implemented. For 1 1/2 years this feature has been wished by a lot of people, as the lively discussion in #413 shows. But now, the conversation #413 has been locked and limited to collaborators ca. a month ago and you cannot participate in the discussion in #413 anymore. Why this limitation of the discussion? Can you provide us, please, with any concrete information, when the missing group SMS feaure will be implemented? Thanks! @moxie0 : I did not want to open a duplicate, but as it is technically impossible to write in #413 which is in general about the missing feature and not about technical details. I saw no other way. Sorry, if the new issue caused trouble. However,my question was not about a regular update service, but was only caused, as this group SMS feature request is open since quite a long time and I was wondering if it is still planned or not. Thanks again.

Manager.description: Hello, the incoming message bubbles in TextSecure 2.21.0 have a colored background (color depends on setting per contact) and the text inside those incoming message bubbles is white. So far that is fine. But: The lock symbol and the date in those incoming message bubbles basically have the same color as the bubble's background, which results in a very low contrast and bad readability. In comparison: The outgoing message bubbles in TextSecure 2.21.0 have a white background and the text inside those outgoing message bubbles is black/dark gray. And the lock symbol and the date in those outgoing message bubbles have the same (or similar) contrasting color as the message text (black/dark gray), which results in a much better readability. So: Could you please change the lock symbol and the date in the incoming message bubbles to a white color? With white they would have a much better contrast to the colored background and would have a much better readability. PS: The phone number in the conversation toolbar (the phone number that is being displayed below the chat partner's name) has the same issue. So it would be nice if you would change that to a white color as well. Regards
Manager.title: Lock symbol and date have very low contrast in incoming message bubbles (phone number in conversation toolbar has the same issue)

Manager.description: Hello, with TextSecure 2.21.0 you can change the color for each contact. When changing the color, the color for the conversation toolbar changes as well. So it's a bit like changing the theme color. However, the attachment button inside the conversation remains blue (default theme color) for example. It would be really nice if you could add an option to TextSecure which would allow to change not just the color for each contact, but also change the theme color globally, so that the color is changed everywhere, including the main screen and settings and so on. Or with other words: Currently the default color in the TextSecure "Light" theme is blue. I'd like to have an option to change this default color to something else. Any chance you could do that? It could be placed under Settings -> Appearance. It would be much appreciated. Regards
Manager.title: Please add option to change default theme color globally

Manager.description: It would be great if one could hide the emoji button and/or replace it with something more useful (e.g. attachment button). There are various reasons why one might not need the emoji button: The keyboard used might already provide an emoji button (as in my case). One might prefer to use/type old-fashioned ASCII emojis, therefore not needing the advanced emoji menu provided by TextSecure. One might not want to use emojis at all. and probably some more that I can't think of...
Manager.title: Option to hide/replace emoji button

Manager.description: Some want uniformity and emoji can get lost in translation but this is not a TextSecure problem and shouldn't be fixed here. Even if it were to be fixed here, why settle on the Apple ones? I can't see how many people have installed Signal but there are 253 ratings, compared to 19,627 ratings for TextSecure. Would iOS users like Android emoji? Probably not. Most people likely prefer whatever they're used to, so it's better to let the system handle the look instead of forcing everyone to use the Apple ones which look really cheap and doesn't fit in at all on Android. TextSecure uses one set of emoji while the rest of the system and other apps uses another now. Also notifications still use the system emoji and apparently nothing can be done about this. The inconsistencies look really sloppy. Adding options is usually not a good idea but the same goes for changing the look that people are used to, so if anything there should be a "compatibility mode" where those who want to make sure nothing gets lost in translation can switch to Apple emoji.
Manager.title: Use system look for emoji or add a "compatibility mode"

Manager.description: No description provided.

Manager.description: When in a secure session with SMS/MMS support enabled, the End secure session button doesn't work to end the session. This may be by design, I'm not sure, but it doesn't work well if I'm sending a regular message to a contact who uses a separate app for regular texts (but who is also registered for TextSecure) and doesn't want to sign in to read any message I send them. If both parties are solely using TextSecure then it doesn't matter, but it should probably be up to the user to decide on the communication protocol.
Manager.title: end secure session + transport options = confusing

Manager.description: When attaching a picture to a text and sending, the sending icon/circle remains on the picture and spins endlessly without disappearing. Recipients sometimes do receive the picture, but the sending icon never stops spinning and wears the battery down unless it is forced to quit. It seems to work a little better with other textsecure users, but not at all with non-textsecure users. I notice the same behavior/problem on a Nexus 6 and HTC One M7 GPE - both with latest version of lollipop.
Manager.title: picture/MMS sending problem to other users? bug?

Manager.description: On Android 4.4.4, TextSecure version 2.21.0 (Sony Xperia Tablet Compact Z3) I found that pasting an extremely long draft message (I was inspired by #3388) into the new message box will bring up the max message length indicator without actually enforcing it. Hence we can get negative characters remaining as shown below. I was still able to send this message without issue to a Signal app; interestingly it causes Signal to crash while trying to load the message. I'm assuming that the desired behavior is to actually enforce message length restrictions, so I will look into this. Steps to Reproduce: Write a really long draft message until you get past 2000 characters. Profit.
Manager.title: Message Length Limits Are Not Enforced

Manager.description: Starting off with the debug log: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/76b13998ebfb86b7142c As we discussed in #3642, I had previously used Titanium Backup, which I had learned after doing so is frowned upon. So I went with the nuclear option of nuking my TextSecure install (wiped data, reinstalled too just for good measure), and starting fresh. The above debug log is after nuking everything. I have a bit more details about what's going on this time, too. First, and probably most importantly, is that the person on the other side of this issue is running WhisperPush version 5.0.2-30bd462d41 on a OnePlus running CM (which is the stock OS on the device). My encrypted push messages to them are good, but I just receive the "Bad encrypted message" error. They can exchange messages with other WhisperPush users, but I'm currently not sure about other TextSecure users. Normal SMS works, but that's probably not shocking. Normal MMS also works. Thoughts/suggestions?
Manager.title: Bad encrypted message from WhisperPush user

Manager.description: Hi, I am a big fan of TextSecure and just discovered the new version (2.32.2) in the Google Play store. Unfortunately, the app is requesting a lot of new permissions. The stated reason is so you can integrate RedPhone later on, which makes sense to make TextSecure more like Signal. While I don't want to imply that I think you guys are doing anything fishy with my data, you will surely understand that people might not install a secure messaging app that has just about access to anything. For example, I cannot see how access to my Calendar is important to exchange messages nor to make phone calls. I think it would really serve you and the community well if you would put an explanation of all the permissions in a prominent place on the open whisper systems website. Having this information easily accessible (link from Google store to that site?) will help users to build trust. Of course anyone can read the code to see that you are not up to anything, but that isn't a good enough answer here since not many people will have the time nor the technical expertise to do so. If your code is audited you could add information about audits on your website, stating who did the audit, with which version of the app and link to their results. Thanks!
Manager.title: New permissions in TextSecure 2.32.2

Manager.description: Contacts without assigned images in the default Google contacts app (also used in the default phone dialer) are assigned a color which normally cannot be changed. Recently however, I've noticed that contacts of the people who are TextSecure registered users do change. The color changes are seemingly random (one was grey, then light blue, red, orange, now purple), and I have yet to find a pattern as when they happen (once it occurred right after I switched back to the contact screen from TextSecure; sometimes I only notice when I open the phone dialer). When it happens all of the contacts of TextSecure users change at once. I'm not exactly sure what causes the problem, but I'm pretty sure it is an issue with TextSecure since all my contacts' colors stay the same except for those who also use TextSecure (even one whom I've never actually texted). Note that this does not apply to the colors that you can assign people within TextSecure; those remain the same. Changing them within TextSecure is probably not the impetus for a change in contacts either, since one that I've never changed within TextSecure has changed in Google contacts. I wonder if it has something to do with the new searching contacts screen in TextSecure? I feel it happens more often after I go to that screen, but that's just a guess. I'm using TextSecure 2.23.2 on a Nexus 5 running Android 5.1.1. Here is a log, if that helps: https://gist.github.com/e5166ff4b9b0ea4b55e0

Manager.description: https://github.com/WhisperSystems/TextSecure/blob/master/src/org/thoughtcrime/securesms/crypto/MasterCipher.java#L65 As it turns out, over the course of loading the items in the conversation list view, Cipher.getInstance is called 32 times from its various initializations and takes ~100ms of main thread time per dataset change, which means ~300-500ms of main thread time per message sent since the cursor is reloaded up to 5 times when a message is sent. Seems like we should either have one MasterCipher instance that we pass along to the various Mms/SmsDatabase readers or at least have the Cipher instances be static singletons.
Manager.title: MasterCipher constructor is sloooooow

Manager.description: I'm on the translate team for TextSecure and SMSSecure for the Dutch language, and I noticed in both projects some inconsistencies. In Dutch, you have 2 forms for the English "you" (ignoring the "thou" form here): the informal "jij", and the more formal "u". I noticed both forms are used in translations, probably depending on the personal preference of the translator of the specific string. In French you have "tu" and "vous", in German "du" and "sie", but I didn't check the French and German translations to see if the forms are mixed there too. I don't know any other languages well enough to say if it can be an issue there. In current Dutch both forms are socially acceptable (although some mostly elder people frown on the use of the informal form). I would suggest the app choose one of the forms to be more consistent. Having both forms mixed makes a sometimes strange impression. I have no strong personal preference for either form. What is the opinion of the developers?
Manager.title: General rules for translations?

E/AndroidRuntime(10381): at org.whispersystems.textsecure.api.messages.TextSecureAttachment$Builder.build(TextSecureAttachment.java:80) E/AndroidRuntime(10381): at org.thoughtcrime.securesms.jobs.MultiDeviceGroupUpdateJob.sendUpdate(MultiDeviceGroupUpdateJob.java:101) E/AndroidRuntime(10381): at org.thoughtcrime.securesms.jobs.MultiDeviceGroupUpdateJob.onRun(MultiDeviceGroupUpdateJob.java:68) E/AndroidRuntime(10381): at org.thoughtcrime.securesms.jobs.MasterSecretJob.onRun(MasterSecretJob.java:18) E/AndroidRuntime(10381): at org.whispersystems.jobqueue.JobConsumer.runJob(JobConsumer.java:76) E/AndroidRuntime(10381): at org.whispersystems.jobqueue.JobConsumer.run(JobConsumer.java:46) Basically, I wanted to check the current status of the TextSecure-Browser project. Since I'm lazy, rather than rebuilding the android application to use the staging server and create another account, I wanted to try to use it to contact my mother and I modified the javascript sources to not use the staging servers (I just removed the -staging string from the urls, as a wild guess) I thought: what's the worse that could happen? the messages might just fail to be delivered well, apparently I was wrong... maybe because the browser plugin expects a newer version of the app, but now I always get the above exception. The problem still happens even after removing/disabling the extension on my browser. The exception doesn't happen if I put the phone in airplane mode, but otherwise it keeps crashing (and showing the related popup) I tried to find a way to disassociate my browser from the phone, but apparently there's no such option. Rebooting the phone didn't help. I frankly could do without TextSecure for a few days... I'd switch back to the normal sms app until this issue would be fixed. But afaik, the only way I could do that, is by uninstalling textsecure/removing the account. Unfortunately this would then create a new key and I'd need to notify my new contacts of the changed fingerprint. I'd like if there was a day to do one of the following things: Tell textsecure to stop connecting altogether Tell textsecure to disable automatic restart Export my textsecure's private key (ok, this is less than ideal, but I'm already suffering from a self-inflicted DOS :P ) Also, I understand that an Android application's lifecycle is not as simple as a normal Java app, so it might not be that easy. But is there no way to have a top-level catch-all exception that recognizes such an issue, increments a counter to detect if the failure was a one-off or is cronical, and does something sane (temporarily disabling itself... don't let the exception bubble up to the system, etc.)? Thank you

Manager.description: The wording of several strings is inconsistent regarding the use of 'SD Card' and 'Storage', although all of these strings refer to the very same thing (as seen in the source code). I'd like to do a small PR correcting that, but want to gather information first what term is prefered. Some things to consider: As far as I know, TextSecure is not able to access a 'real' SD card when using KitKat or Lollipop. The term 'SD card' could be confusing to users with no SD card slot on their phone. The concept of a 'emulated SD card' could be even more confusing to those users ('There are no power users'). Possible terms: SD card storage device storage external storage (thx, @2-4601) anything else? I'd appreciate your input!
Manager.title: Wording: 'SD Card' vs. 'Storage'

Manager.description: This is my first post. I just compared textsecure with whatsapp and found that many features is required. Hereby i try to list the most required features. Audio call Brodcast Profile Pic Status Last seen Typing Wallpapper or Custom Background Email Chat Location Share Delete Account Change Number Optiin to Auto download media I just mentioned above features after comparison with whatsapp. Its not necessary that we build application like whatsapp but above mentioned features is required for any messenger application. I also found some issue in ts. Like if you add any friends in group after that admin can not remove any friends from the group. Admin must remove any member from group. When some members post text message in group then notification shows that this friends post text message but does not show the group name, so we think that this is private message but actually its group message. Other issue is we only select one image at time, we must select 10 to 20 image at time. Sorry for my bad English but i tried to contribute to this awesome app. Thanks Bahadursinh
Manager.title: Most Required Features

Manager.description: As I don't use TextSecure for sending or receiving SMS messages, I would like to be able to completely disable this functionality. In this way I won't be allowed to send unencrypted messages using TextSecure, not even by error. Currently if I long press the send button, or if I specify a phone number that is not using TextSecure, I am allowed to send a plain text SMS. Especially in the latter case it is not immediate to realize that this is happening. I think that the average user expects to disable any kind of SMS operation when setting "SMS and MMS" to Off. Thanks!
Manager.title: Completely disable SMS sending

Manager.description: Currently, if someone gets the ability to get my SMSes, such as by stealing my SIM card or somehow intercepting them at the carrier, or number cloning, then the only thing standing in the way of that person impersonating me to a user I've already chatted to is the key mismatch warning. Some users will click through that without thinking. And someone who's never chatted to me before will not get any warning because of TOFU. Since I don't think there's any intention to aggressively push users to manually verify key fingerprints, it would be nice if I could add a passphrase to my registration that would not let someone register a new device with my phone number without also having that passphrase. Since this adds some friction, it would be reasonable for it to be opt-in; that is to say, once I register my number for the first time, I should be able to go into the settings and enable the passphrase requirement. The biggest drawback I can see is that if I give up my phone number and then it is reassigned, someone else will be stuck unable to use textsecure with that number. I can't really think of a perfect way to solve this, but expiring a registration that hasn't been used at all in some period of time, say 12 months, would probably be a reasonable approach. Alternatively, instead of just requiring use, the server could periodically send the client a liveness check of some sort (via push), and clear the registration if those don't succeed for some shorter period of time (3 months?) if the app isn't even responding at all.
Manager.title: Second factor for re-registering with the server

Manager.description: Use case: I and my contact are "push registered", but at various times one of us goes offline for a few hours and would like to seamlessly switch to SMS. Explanation: I only use data when connected to WiFi, so SMS is prefered communication channel much of the time. This is common amongst my contacts here in Europe, but some have mobile data. Issue: TS seems to switch to PUSH whenever sender has data (or even if previous conversation was PUSH). This leads to frustrating undelivered messages if sender simply hits reply without deliberately forcing SMS. Feature request: When there is evidence that the sender or recipient is offline, there should be some way to prefer SMS. Two possible ways to avoid these undelivered PUSH replies: Seamless SMS fallback if either person is not online. If "seamless" is not an option: receiving an SMS should trigger SMS mode for the conversation. I understand that defaulting to SMS is problematic now that SMS encryption is gone, but this could be an "Advanced" option for nerds like me. Can add a warning as modal, or in settings: "Warning: this could cost you money or accidentally lead to insecure SMS communication." Related: This behavior was outlined by @cramu here: WhisperSystems#984 (comment) If sender or recipient are not reachable (because mobile data is not available) a popup appears, warning the sender that the message could be delayed and asking him for confirmation or to edit his message and send via SMS/MMS. Issue #678 looked promising, but that bug is huge, stale and it is unclear what was finally decided upon / implemented.
Manager.title: SMS fallback not triggered if recipient offline

Manager.description: When your contact's key changes and you try to scan their QR code through the "You may wish to verify this contact" link the keys won't match because the QR scan expects the old key even though the hex fingerprint screen shows the new key. Steps: Your contact's key changes They send you a message. You tap the message to open the "The identifying material for contact has changed..." dialog Tap the link "You may wish to verify this contact." Notice that you see two fingerprints on this verification screen (and their fingerprint is the new one) Open the QR code scanning mode You either a) get a toast "Recipient has no identity key!" (in the case your contact has no previous key anymore - e.g. they unregistered at some point) OR b) Barcode Scanner opens, you scan their QR code, and you will get the dialog saying "WARNING, the scanned key DOES NOT match! ..." You can see the mismatch when you compare the fingerprint verification screen opened through the lock icon vs. the screen opened through the "You may wish..." link. As expected the former shows the old fingerprint and the latter shows the new one. However in the latter screen the QR code matching seems to still use the old key. Nexus 4, 5.1.1, TS 2.26.1 and before
Manager.title: Key's QR code never matches when opened through "You may wish to verify this contact"

Since a couple of weeks almost all TS-using contacts are shown twice in the list of TS users (and once under "All contacts"). Only newly added TS contacts are listed once. It started when I used TS 2.25.3. Today I noticed that one contact was listed (in the conversations list and in TS' contacts list) without her name, only by her number. Although the native contacts app shows a perfectly fine entry, when I tried to call that person, her name was not shown when dialing (as it would normally happen); instead her number was listed as an "other" number---in the native contacts app, her number is labeled "mobile". In fact, when I tried to edit the contact in the native contacts app, at the bottom there is an entry for TextSecure (that cannot be edited) that indicates that the number is stored on the phone with the label "other". (In turn, when I restrict the contacts to app to show contacts stored on the phone only, it lists none, as I would expect.) Does that imply that TS creates a local copy of the CardDAV phone number on the phone? In fact, said contact is one the many duplicates. I played around and "separated" and re-"joined" the varying accounts via which I'm connected to said person in the native contacts app. Now her name (instead of her number only) is listed twice again in the list of TS users, but the two entries are not listed in two subsequent rows, but the first entry jumped to the very top of the list, before the names starting with an A. I repeated that exercise with another duplicate entry, to the same effect: it seems that a second list of TS users is created that is alphabetically ordered and stacked on top of the other one. Apologies for this lengthy post. The only previous issue I found that mentions CardDAV is WhisperSystems#2533, which "solved" itself when the user updated to a higher Android version.
Manager.title: Problems with properly accessing contacts stored via CardDAV on older Android devices?

Manager.description: Device Model: MotoG Android Version: 5.1.1 (CyanogenMod 12.1.20150820-NIGHTLY) TextSecure Version: 2.26.5 Situation: PersonA and PersonB both use TextSecure. PersonA uses TextSecure as their default SMS application. PersonB does not use TextSecure as their default SMS application. PersonB does not always have a network connection and will at times send SMS messages to PersonA. Expected Behaviour: SMS messages sent from PersonB to PersonA will be shown as green in TextSecure. Current Behaviour: SMS messages sent from PersonB to PersonA are shown in blue. Problems Caused: PersonA does not know if the message sent from PersonB was sent securely. PersonA may assume PersonB has connectivity due to them sending messages, and thus wrongly assume their messages have been received. PersonA may not know over which medium (SMS/TextSecure) they are expected to reply to PersonB.
Manager.title: SMS messages received from TextSecure users are blue not green
