Manager.description: The prequisite would be including barcode scanner into TextSecure/Signal and to move the "end secure session" to the three dot menu. Tapping the lock would enable QR code verification immediately. When Axolotl protocol assigns Alice and Bob roles to devices by comparing the base key, they could also be used assign roles for QR-code verification: e.g. display QR code on Alice's device and open camera on Bob's device. Bob could then scan both fingerprints from Alice's device at the same time: It could both verify that Bob's device had received the proper key from Alice, and that the proper key was delivered to Alice's device. After verification, Bob's device would either report successful verification or MITM risk. Here's a mockup I made: This approach would reduce the amount of user interaction from nine taps to two, and after crude measuring, verification would be 20 seconds faster.
Manager.title: Proposal to speed up QR code verification

Manager.description: Using Signal 3.0.1 (beta) for Android on a Nexus 5. Debug log (though I doubt you'll want it) is https://gist.github.com/526f0bbf1de80801e008 On WhatsApp, when I attach a contact, it brings up the contact's record with checkboxes next to each item of information that you have for him/her (e.g. numbers and email addresses) and you can choose which you want to include. You then click send and it sends them all together as a record, formatted specially. Clicking on it in the WhatsApp chat then allows you to add that information to your contacts (giving you the option to add it to an existing contact, or create a new contact, as is normal for receiving a contact). It also has a clever little message icon under the contact record that allows you to send a WhatsApp message to that contact straight away without adding them to your address book. The interface in Signal is much less developed. When you select attaching contact information on the same contact, it only shows me the phone numbers for the contact (rather than the email addresses) and selecting one just inserts the number alone (with no name or formatting). I would like to see Signal send a proper contact record with a similar flow to that described above for WhatsApp, at least if the recipient is also a Signal/TextSecure user and the message is being sent over the data channel.
Manager.title: Attaching/Sending contact info should attach a contact record, rather than a number

Manager.description: Not sure if this is really a bug or my device and ROM just suck but I will report anyway. The microphone of my Huawei U8800 does not seem to work with Signal. After establishing the call the other party does not hear anything. I've gone through all the system settings and there's nothing that should prevent the microphone from working. It works with regular calls. And it sort of works with Google Hangouts calls (there's static noise but the voice goes through). But for Signal there's no sound at all. I don't know if RedPhone works. I tried to install it and register but the voice verification I received was silent so I couldn't test with it. As this Huawei is my test device and it has cheap, outdated hardware with a weird, outdated and rooted ROM I don't mind if this will ever work. But in the case that this is a Signal bug and it concerns other devices too here's a log: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/cad04e7a57887989ee08 There are a lot of these in there: E/AudioHardwareMSM7X30( 115): AudioStreamInVoip::read : device is already open Signal 3.0.1 Huawei U8800, 4.0.4
Manager.title: Microphone does not work in an ICS Huawei device

Manager.description: I was conversing with a friend who uses Signal. We typically use regular SMS, as my friend is accustomed to using iMessage by default. On occasion, we converse via encrypted messaging. So on my end, my conversation thread is a mix of SMS and encrypted messages. This is the case with a few other friends as well Today we were conversing via SMS, and my friend sent an MMS, which was likely just a picture of what we were talking about. I tapped on the MMS to download it, and TS immediately crashed I opened TS again and entered my passphrase, and it immediately crashed. This continued to happen, over and over. The app has become unusable I still receive SMS and encrypted messages, and notifications. If I enter my passphrase, TS will crash, but I can then see message previews in the pull down notification window. I can even use the "Mark All As Read" option Rebooting my phone hasn't helped. I asked a few other friends to message me via TS, and to send TS messages and MMS' with picture attachments, in hopes that some state of the app would change. Nothing has worked I'm on the latest version of Android and TS My debug log: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/98234d272af3935fe776 Thank you
Manager.title: TS crashes as soon as I enter my passphrase, every single time

Manager.description: The following has happened for the first time, after many months of TS working flawlessly on this phone: https://gist.github.com/anonymous/723ba29a67dcafdd3664 I sent a plain SMS message as expected (and done many times before) with TS. It was received by the adressee. Hours later, I found the GSM network "unavailable" (supposedly due to GSM hiccup, as the phone wasn't moved nor touched). I enabled, then re-disabled flight mode in order to cleanly reconnect to the tower. As soon as this happened, I was briefly notified that TS had troubles sending a message, and TS apparently started to flood the send queue with hundreds of resending attempts. Unfortunately, many (if not all) succeeded, giving the stunned recipient a massive SMS flood / DOS experience. There was a system popup dialog asking if I wanted to allow TS to send the high number of SMS messages it tried to, but the phone (S5, normally very fast and slick ROM) was so busy sending and playing sound alerts that dialog didn't seem to care about my answer (or was immediately replaced by a new instance, I don't know). I shut off the phone and restarted, but as soon as GSM was connected, the mess continued. Alas, I did not manage to capture any logs. When the phone finally got reponsive again, they appeared empty (I looked with System Tuner Pro).
Manager.title: TS resending the last sent SMS some 100 times after "network unavailable" and flight mode cycle

Manager.description: My friend is in a timezone 1h ahead of mine. When they send me a message, TS shows the time as one hour ahead of the current local time. There are two problems with this: It is confusing for the user when following the conversation / reading the message. The conversation list shows the conversation as 23h in the past, sorted below a conversation that was only a few "proper" hours in the past. Possible reason for the time difference: My friend did not set the timezone, but the time, when traveling to their current location. Thus our timezones are the same, but their time is wrong. I did not ask them to confirm that, yet. What I would expect from TS: When a conversation is in the future, show it above all others (sorted by relative/signed time difference), instead of sorting it by absolute/unsigned time difference. The server could append its own time, so that the receiving client has three times: sent-by-sender, received-by-server, received-by-recipient. Then: TS could show all three times in the message details. In the conversation view, it could show the time that (roughly) agrees with the others, filtering the third from the user's view by default. E.g. show an average of the two (of all three) times with the least difference.
Manager.title: Messages from the future

Manager.description: Hi, one issue that comes up frequently when I make TextSecure/Signal calls with extended family is uncomfortable fingerprint-verification word choices. For example, today I had to explain to my parents why the words "retouch puberty" came up on their phone. Some other possibilities that will probably happen to people at some point: "newborn puberty" "showgirl penetrate" "facial escapade" "adult visitor" 95% of the time it doesn't matter at all, but if it were possible, I'd prefer that the word combinations be extremely boring. I want to be able to recommend Signal to anyone without worrying about whether they'll get weird words and end up being creeped out. I'd be happy to go through and change the words in src/org/thoughtcrime/redphone/crypto/zrtp/SASCalculator.java, but I think there may be some additional work to do around versioning. Is changing this list possible / realistic? If you all think this should be changed too, I'm happy to help... I was building TS from source for a while but stopped a few months ago. I don't mind getting everything set up again if it means this will get changed.
Manager.title: Awkward/uncomfortable fingerprint-verification word combinations

Manager.description: At least some users in Mexico are having difficulty registering with Signal. As far as I've heard, this is an ongoing problem that also affected TextSecure. The symptoms I've seen are that 1) SMS registration does not work - the registration times out unsuccessfully. 2) The user can successfully register using voice verification, and an encrypted session can be initialized, and messages sent back and forth. 3) However, the Mexican phone then decides that it is no longer registered, and encrypted messages cannot be sent or received. I suspect this issue may be related to #3360 - there are multiple valid formats for a Mexican phone number. I've posted a debug log.
Manager.title: (some) users in Mexico cannot register / can register only temporarily

Manager.description: Hello As @moxie0 stated here: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=10498671 he would be pleased to see a 'API-compatible open source implementation of play services' to make it possible to use signal with GMS without the need to install GAPPS. Well, there is now good progress in this direction with the project microG GmsCore. This aims to be a 'framework to allow applications designed for Google Play Services to run on systems, where Play Services is not available'. Would it be possible to accept this as an alternative? At the moment this project can be used to run Signal without GAPPS. The disadvantage is that microg GmsCore needs to fake app signatures at the moment to get Signal running. This is a huge security risk. If Signal would accept microg GmsCore as an alternative to the proprietary implementation, there would be no need anymore to tamper with the android security system. What do you Signal developers think about this and would you consider this as an alternative? Kind regards. PS: I am not affiliated with this project. More can be found here: http://forum.xda-developers.com/android/apps-games/app-microg-gmscore-floss-play-services-t3217616 https://github.com/microg
Manager.title: microg GmsCore as free alternative for proprietary Gms

Manager.description: I guess this is somehow related to #4029, but that one seems to be fixed - while I'm still experiencing that kind of issue. Almost all of my contacts appear a couple of times in Signal's contact list - with all of their different phone numbers. So far, so good (expected behaviour). But many have additional duplicate entries with the same number (it's always a mobile number) listed twice. One of them has the format +12 345 67890 (which is exactly how I format all of my phone book's entries). The other one (the duplicate) has the very same number, but formatted as +1234567890 (a format not to be found in my phone book). I've noticed that - as far as I looked - each of the contacts with this kind of duplicate has an WhatsApp entry in Android's phone book (actually 2 entries - one for calls and one for messages). Interestingly, though, the WhatsApp entries in Android's phone book are also (sort of correctly) formatted as +12 345 67890. I don't necessarily say that the WhatsApp entries are the culprit (i. e. they confuse Signal). But it surely looks like they are. It has been like this for a long time, but I just took the time to inspect this more closely. I'm using vanilla Android 6 on a Nexus 5 with Signal 3.3.0.
Manager.title: Contacts with WhatsApp appearing twice in Signal's contact list

Manager.description: I see that with 8fd0ea3 the quick picture mode uses the front facing camera by default. I personally don't like it, but if you think that for most people it's more "useful" like this, then fine. I suggest to make Signal remember the last used camera (either per-conversation or application-wide). This would make most people happy and I think it fits within your development guidelines (don't add settings, ...).
Manager.title: Wishlist: please let the quick camera remember the last used mode (front/rear)

Manager.description: No description provided.
Manager.title: Feature Request: Support fingerprint reader as an alternative to PIN for encryption

Manager.description: Signal 3.3.0, other side the latest iOS version. Yesterday I received a Signal call. While calling (on speaker) I received a (little bit) delayed Signal message from the same person. I pulled down the notification drawer to see tghe message and got in the standard Signal messages screen. When I pushed the back button I more or less expected to re-enter the call screen but I got in the list of conversations. Is that intended? When I re-opened the conversation with the person who was calling (we could continue to talk during this) and pushed the call button I re-entered the Redphone call screen.
Manager.title: Is this screen flow intended?

Manager.description: If I only add one person or confirm the group configuration without any changes all participants are listed as joined and the unchanged group name is listed as new group name. Found in build 3.3.1. For me it looks like a regression that has possibly been introduced with the fix that replaces numbers with names for joined participants.
Manager.title: Group update always lists all group parameters (regression)

Manager.description: I've noticed that many wiki pages need an update and/or are missing. For examle the 'redphone protocol' page is not reachable since the github repo was taken down. Another thing i noticed is the protocol is still called textsecure protocol v2. Since this is the only protocol signal has ever supported i suggest we just call it the signal protocol. (this is kind of off topic but is why I was looking for the wiki page: how much is shared between the messaging and calling protocols? Is the calling protocol zrtp as claimed here? If this is true it means it does not have the self healing properties of the axolotl ratchet, right?)
Manager.title: update documentation

Manager.description: I have friends who always want to mute certain groups. Currently, it's only possible to mute groups one week at a time, which can get really cumbersome. I'd be convenient for them to have the option to mute these groups for a really long time. Is there any rationale not to extend the muting options with longer periods, like "1 year" or "forever" (9999 years)?
Manager.title: Add longer muting periods

Manager.description: When I send invitations via SMS, the contact selection is not reseted if I want to sent invitations again. I would expect, that no contacts are selected, if I continue sending invitations. Device : LGE Nexus 4 (occam) Android : 5.1.1 (2237560, LMY48T) Memory : 43M (0.03% used, 192M max) Memclass: 192 OS Host : kpfj15.cbf.corp.google.com App : Signal 3.3.1 How to reproduce: In Main Screen Menu "Invite friends" Click "Send SMS" Select a contact Click "Send to 1 friend(s)" Confirm "Send 1 SMS invite(s)?" Dialog with "Yes" Back at invitation screen with "Invitations sent!" Notification Click "Send SMS" again Previous contact selection is still active Expected: No contacts are selected
Manager.title: Contact selection not reseted after sending invitations

Manager.description: You probably know of things like charities using numbers such as 85474 (made up number) to donate. Attempting to send a text to such a number from Signal results in the country code being added, so from where I live, it became +4485474 and thus failed.
Manager.title: Texts to premium numbers such as charities don't work

Manager.description: Hello. I wish there was a way of telling who has Signal and who hasn't immediately by looking at the contact's name on the "front page" of Signal. It would only take a tiny lock next to their name. As it is right now, there is no way of teling if a user has Signal or not, unless you click their name. It's not a big deal, I know. But if the long term goal of Signal is to compete with WhatsApp I would say this feature is a necessity. Sorry for a dizzy post, I've had the flu for quite some time now.
Manager.title: Show who has Signal and who hasn't in the list of text messages

Manager.description: Since commit 5757962 was added, you can now install Signal on WiFi-only devices like tablets. However, if you do this, and register using the same phone number as your phone with a Signal install, your phone will no longer be able to receive or send Signal messages (and vice versa). The obvious solution is better multi-device support, which is already on the roadmap. But until then, there should be some warning that you can only have one device per number right now.
Manager.title: registering with the same phone number breaks original registration
material-dialogs not found on maven

Manager.description: One contact got yellow as colour and it not very good for reading their messages.
Manager.title: Some conversation colours are horrible to read

Manager.description: Signal 3.3.1 Call someone using headphones Turn the display off with power button on phone After a few seconds the display is switched on again. There's no way to keep the screen off during the call. Proximity sensor turning it off doesn't help when you're not holdint the phone to your ear and it shouldn't turn the display on unless pressing the power button again.
Manager.title: Don't turn display on during calls

Manager.description: Low volume (both hands-free talking enabled and disabled) and very poor quality. Found with Signal 3.1.1 on Samsung Galaxy Note 4 device. The competing open source app https://www.simlar.org/en/ is louder and clearer on the same network conditions.
Manager.title: Low volume and very poor quality

Manager.description: White in the middle of an ongoing conversation encryption stopped working. The other one can send me encrypted messages but I have to fall back to SMS. He also not listed as Signal contact any longer. Log: https://gist.github.com/e34eb0695e27a303f2b0
Manager.title: Sudden switch to unencrypted conversation

Manager.description: Low volume (both hands-free talking enabled and disabled) and very poor quality. Found with Signal 3.3.1 on Samsung Galaxy Note 4 device. The competing open source app https://www.simlar.org/en/ is louder and clearer on the same network conditions. Note: This is NOT a duplicate of #4244 since that issue is about builds earlier than 3.3.1.

Manager.description: I think it's highly non-obvious that you can pull down the contact list to refresh it. Manager.description: Previous behavior (with Redphone): If I initiated a call from the system dialer for a user that was registered with Redphone, I received a pop-up asking if I wanted to upgrade the call to a Redphone call. In addition, calls showed up in the list of sent, received, and missed calls in the system dialer even if placed via Redphone. Current Behavior: With the introduction of Signal, there is no longer any dialer integration. Why the change matters: I think this was a nice feature as it means a user could simply initiate calls through the system dialer as opposed to opening Signal to initiate a call. This make it more likely that unsophisticated users, like my mother, would actually make secure calls since they don't have to do anything differently. A Google search revealed another user brought up this issue, but attempting to access that page results in a 404. I didn't see any existing issues in Github. Tested with Signal 3.1.1 and 3.3.1 on Cyanogenmod 11 (Milestone 11), Android 4.4.4, on a One Plus One (A0001).

Manager.description: Over the last several days, I've noticed that messages are occasionally not being delivered (one checkmark) and I am unable to initiate a secure call to said contact. I confirmed that the user's phone was on at the time, he had a data connection (Wifi), and in fact the Signal app was opened in the background. The user was able to receive emails and regular phone calls without issue. Restarting the Signal app fixed the problem. In addition, after restarting the app, he recevied all my previous messages. This user was running Android 4.4.4 on a One Plus One with Signal 3.1.1. I had a similar issue with a Signal iOS user (Signal 2.2, iOS 8.4.1, iPhone 5S). Messages to that user went through nearly instantly but I was unable to initiate a secure call. However, the user could call me via Signal, and my phone rang nearly instantly. When the user closed the Signal app, I was able to initiate a call, and it rang on her phone within a second. I understand that Google Cloud Messaging is believed it be causing delayed message delivery intermittently. However, the behavior I'm seeing appears to impact both iOS and Android clients, the messages are not merely delayed but do not arrive at all until the app is restarted, and when the recipient restarts his/her Signal applicaiton, new messages sent to that user are delivered within seconds. As noted above, calls are also impacted. I can't see why restarting Signal would suddenly make GCM more reliable, so it seems there may be a bug in Signal causing the delays and inability to initiate secure calls. Would logs useful? If so, do you want them for me (sender) or the recipient that isn't receiving the messages?
Manager.title: Signal messages delayed and unable to initiate secure calls until recipient restarts Signal app

Manager.description: When creating a group with one or more contacts which aren't registered with Signal, there is a very clear notification that an MMS group will be created, which could lead to additional costs. Current experience: When someone unregisteres from Signal while s/he is part of a group, the other group members receive error messages saying the message couldn't be sent, even tough it is in fact sent to the remaining members of the group. The error message is even more confusing, because the message has the same "click for more details" notification next to it like messages that failed to send because the server couldn't be reached. In the latter case you can see to which members the message failed to send and just click "resend" to resolve the issue. In the "a member of a signal group unregistered" case there are no more details and nothing to do for the user. Proposed experience: When Signal notices that a group member is no longer registered, there should be a notification that this member was removed from the group and has to be readded manually if they register again. A fallback to MMS would probably be the worst option, because it could create huge intransparent costs e.g. for European users, leading to the immeadiate removal of the app. I'm looking forward to your thoughts and improvement ideas! Edit: The messages are usually delivered even if the error message is shown. But the constant error messages confuse users and make them loose faith in the app.
Manager.title: Improve error handling if a member of a signal group unregisters

Manager.description: Latency: Perhaps the most notable difference between making a Signal and a standard cell phone call is the latency encountered. In fact, it was the very first comment one of my friends mentioned when we initiated the call. RTT appears to be at least 1 second even when the person I'm calling is relatively close (several hundred miles on the East cost of the US, where Signal has a server - can't find the link now but Moxie published a blog post indicating where Signal has servers for routing calls). However, when I call the same person on Jitsi, the RTT is below 100 ms, and latency is barely noticeable. We are both connecting via Wifi using broadband connections with at least 50 Mbit down and 10 Mbit of upload capacity for him and 100/100 for me (Fiber on my end, cable on his). Jitsi shows effectively 0% packet loss and sub 5ms jitter with RTT typically around 50 ms. Thus, I would not expect significant latency in Signal given our geographic proximity and high speed, relatively low-latency connections. In fact, my Signal calls to the US from China seemed to have similar latency to the East Cost - East Coast US calls. Audio Quality: The audio quality in Signal appears to generally be worse than a cell phone call, and is significantly worse than Jitsi or Skype (both of which use wideband codecs - SILK for Skype IIRC and Opus @ 48 Khz for Jitsi). In addition, I notice more cut-outs and audio distortions with Signal. Again, both callers are on Wifi with high-speed broadband connections and are in relatively close physical proximity. I would imagine that implementing Opus in Signal would improve call quality generally, particularly if it is allowed to run in a wideband setting, as Opus is superior to Speex at all bitrates/sampling rates per the documentation. However, I'm rather perplexed about the subjectively high latency. Note: Wasn't sure whether to post this here or on the mailing list. Please advise.
Manager.title: Generally poor audio quality and high latency with Signal calls

Manager.description: When sending a media message with a PNG attachment, Signal converts the PNG to JPEG (and scales it) before sending. Later, when choosing to save the image from the conversation, this JPEG is saved with a ".png" extension. This occurs because Attachment#updateAttachmentData replaces the attachment data stream without updating the attachment content type. Steps to reproduce Take a completely unamusing screenshot (PNG) to send to a contact Open Signal Open the conversation with said contact Tap the Attach button Tap the Image button Select the new screenshot from the documents provider Observe the draft media message with thumbnail Tap the Send button Wait for the media message progress to complete (converting to JPEG, scaling, sending) Long press the media message Tap the Save button Reluctantly embrace the security warning Observe the new Signal-yyyy-mm-dd-hhmmss.png in /sdcard/Pictures adb pull this curious file and check check it Behold, a JPEG in disguise Device info: Nexus 5, stock Android 6.0 MRA58K, Signal 3.5.0 (473e470) App state: Signal registered, SMS enabled, default SMS app
Manager.title: PNG -> scaled JPEG attachment -> saves with ".png" extension

Manager.description: Signal can literally expire any second, so that out of a sudden you are not able to send messages anymore (well, of course only if you do not update it for 90 days). Immediately updating the app right then might not be possible if you require a wifi connection. I am sure that this is not a problem for any of the people involved here, but for other non tech-savvy users it can be (firsthand experience). Reasons for apps not updating automatically: new permission required (happened before the RedPhone integration) not enough free space on the device available for some other reason... it is not uncommon for me to see 10 or so pending app updates on other peoples's devices There should be a time-triggered warning, or some other trigger to inform the user beforehand.
Manager.title: Bad UX with expiring Signal versions

Manager.description: Hi, So I just received an update of Signal with complete translation to Hebrew, and it's WONDERFUL. Manager.description: Feature proposal: Add delivery date/time for outgoing SMS/Signal messages in "message details". In a similar way that we can see when the incoming message was both sent and delivered in the "message details" dialog, add this functionality to the outgoing messages. Right now, only "sent" date/time is shown there. Regarding privacy implications - this will not change anything there, no extra info is required from the recipient to provide. Just present the already non-secret "second checkmark's timestamp" in a more convenient way to the user (via "message details" dialog). Just as the "second checkmark" itself, the usability of this if obvious, especially if a contact in a bad reception area and you don't get the "second checkmark" right away. For SMS, this functionality is provided by most SMS apps if "delivery receipts" are enabled. So in a way, using Signal as SMS client in current form reduces this sms functionality (so for SMS case it might as well be considered as a bug).
Manager.title: Add delivery date/time for outgoing SMS/Signal messages info

Manager.description: This is a small change, but it should improve user experience. Manager.description: I installed Signal on Android and very shortly after got messages from two friends who both use Signal congratulating me on installing it. The two conversations were colored primary red and primary green. I assumed that these colors signified some meaning about the conversations like maybe the green one was secure and the red one was insecure. I did some Googling and found Issue #945 which seemed to imply that the issue color indicated the transport medium that the message arrived by. I asked @mfb and he figured out what was going on, that these colors were meant to differentiate conversations from each other. I'd like to recommend / feature request, excluding meaning rich colors from use as differentiating conversation colors, at least initially, to avoid confusing the user. If for example the first two conversations were in pastels or in pretty much any two colors other than red and green (which have a very strong visual meaning of stop/go success/error good/bad) I think I would have begun to intuit that the colors were for conversation differentiation. I'd also say that if it started out with pastels or some other non-meaning-rich colors and I later encountered red and green conversations I'd probably intuit they were just there for differentiation. Since it looks like conversation color is driven directly by the contacts name I'm not sure it would make sense to tweak the initial colors as the user begins using the app. Since, by my read, of the list of colors, only red and green have a strong meaning. All the others seem not meaning rich to me, maybe just remove red and green. Problem there is that existing users mapping of which conversations have which colors would change, possibly confusing people. So, hopefully someone here has a better idea of a solution here than what I've come up with.
Manager.title: Exclude meaning rich colors for conversation differentiation initially

Manager.description: When a Bluetooth audio device is already connected and selected for call audio, Signal uses it just fine. However, when you want to swap an already-established call to a Bluetooth headset, there is no means to do so without disconnecting the call and establishing a new one. (In addition, when you start a call on Bluetooth and then wander out of range, such as might happen when you leave your phone in your vehicle at a gas station, many phones will silently redirect the call back to the standard ear speaker. In these cases, when you get back out to the vehicle, these phones typically will reconnect with the Bluetooth headset but will not redirect the call audio back to the headset.) So, in addition to the speakerphone option, I would like to see a Bluetooth option that would attempt to change the call audio stream to a Bluetooth headset. Security considerations: This could potentially pose a threat when there is a Bluetooth sniffer near the phone that's trying to use Bluetooth (given the differences between Bluetooth encryption and Signal encryption). It does not impact security of the call stream over the cellular or wifi networks. This would seem to be no more risky than the current state of being willing to use a Bluetooth headset if it is configured before the call starts. Please do not take Bluetooth functionality away; several of my contacts will refuse to use Signal any longer if they cannot use it with their Bluetooth headsets.
Manager.title: No means to change audio stream to Bluetooth headset after establishment

Manager.description: Updated (2016-02-27): Version: 3.12 Nexus is ok. x5pro still misbehaving. The bug is likely in the rom. But since there are so many affected devices and related regressions as system and apps are updated, I'll keep this issue open unless told otherwise. 2016-02-23: Version: 3.11.1 Affected devices: Nexus 4 and Doogee X5 Pro. Stock unrooted roms or rooted roms regardless. Possibly dupe of: #1037 This used to only affect the x5pro but now the nexus recently shown the same bug. Also, Whatsapp doesn't display this bug so this is likely a Signal issue \ workaround-able android issue. Previously: Notes: Version: 3.8.1 This is was originally thought to be an OEM related bug. Now it's been confirmed on two separate devices from two separate OEMs. One of which is running a custom ROM... Also, I have no idea how process and memory management actually works in Dalvik\ART so the terminology section is my ad-hoc attempt to work around this. Terminology: Foregrounded: Visible. Full-screened. "The running" app. Backgrounded: Closed. Still visible in the Recents tasks list. Shown to be running under in Settings->Apps->Running Apps. Daemonized: Closed, Not visible in Recents. But still shown running as a service in Settings->Apps->Running Apps. Killed: Closed, Not visible in Recents. Not shown under Settings->Apps->Running Apps. Scenario: 2 clients; 1 Nexus 4 (works as expected), 1 Doogee X5Pro (misbehaving). Working: 1. When both phones have Signal foregrounded, messages pass back and forth smoothly and instantaneously. 2. When Signal is Foregrounded on one phone while backgrounded on the other, a notification appears correctly. 3. When the Nexus has Signal daemonized after being swiped off Recents, while the X5pro is sending through a foregrounded Signal, a notification appears correctly. 4. When the X5pro has Signal backgrounded, notifications appear correctly while the Nexus is sending them through the foregrounded Signal client. Not-working: Swiping off Signal from Recents doesn't daemonize the process. Instead it's killed and Signal messages fail to transfer. SMSs still work (I'm guessing a separate android daemon\service handles that). Extra-credits: When remaining opened under Recents, Signal is indicated to occupy 26mb. When daemonized it's 6mb. Since I have no idea how Dalvik\Android actually manages memory, I can't say if that's address space (virtual memory) or resident memory or just what the Dalvik's process heap is pointing at... TLDR: Seems on some phones, swiping off Signal from the Recents tasks-list doesn't daemonize properly. Instead, Signal is closed off entirely and Signal messages fail to transfer. Edit: Updated reflecting further feedback. And version.
Manager.title: unable to receive messages if swiped off from Recents

Anyways, upon installing or updating (I don't recall which it was) to the latest version of Signal, they received a number of 'X is on Signal, say hey!' notifications. Obviously this was very disconcerting, as the first thought was that people on the other end might be receiving similar notifications. Is that the case, or are they "one-way" in the sense that you only receive notifications for numbers that you already have in your contacts? Manager.description: Hello there i noticed that in SMSSecure (i know where i am) there is kind of a glitch that, if you send out a key-exchange message to a non-SMSSecure user and sayed User forwards you that exact Message, the communication is afterwards shown to be encrypted which it most-likely is but with the own publickey which will result in more gibberish being send to the user. I am not sure if this affects Signal too, which it probably won't as the server automatically checks if sayed user has indeed Signal installed but a basic routine that checks if the send back publickey at key-exchange is indeed not identical to ones own publickey would be appreciated. Truth be told i am by no means a Cryptographer and can not estimate how trivial if at all such a routine would be to be implemented and even if this is something you consider important as it is a probably a rather rare occasion. I am just forwarding this to the crypto-guys which created the underlying protocol in the first place Greetings, Henry Kratom
Manager.title: Check if Identical Publickey is send back at keyexchange

Manager.description: Id like to be able to use signal on my wifi tablet without needing a phone #. Also, requiring a user to sign up with a unique identifier like a phone number seems to be like the first obvious identifier we would not want to require a user to submit if we are interesting in anonymity. Snowden talks about unique identifier databases. Bleep allows account creation with just a key pair. My request is not to require the user to submit identification information on a device that tracks their physical location, can be pinpointed by a stingray, and is most likely directly linked to their billing records. It also makes it a pain to keep a signal account portable when a user changes phone numbers. If a user wants to submit their phone number so that their contacts can locate them that way, fine, but as a requirement its a total game killer.
Manager.title: Use Signal without needing a phone #

Manager.description: Hi @moxie0, on poor network conditions I often see that Signal indicates a failed delivery while some group members have received the message. Signal does not indicate which group member have received the message and which not. Re-sending leads to some group members receiving the message with multiple copies. In order to avoid such issues it should be possible to implement a solution based on the following principle: Indicate the server that a message to x group members is prepared to be sent Transfer all encrypted messages (for each participant) to the server The server waits until messages for each participant have been received The server delivers the messages Found with Signal 3.9.1.
Manager.title: Group messages partially delivered on poor network conditions

Manager.description: Contact list displays names with accents in the wrong order resulting in people named "√Ålvaro" being sorted after "Zacar√≠as" (not able to attach image at the moment). I think COLLATE LOCALIZED in https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/blob/master/src/org/thoughtcrime/securesms/contacts/ContactsDatabase.java (line 150) will do the trick but i'm not a programmer. According to what I've found: [LOCALIZED] It instructs SQLite to sort non-ASCII characters appropriately. Chars with diacritics (some call them accents) have higher byte codes than the character Z, so a plain ASCII sort wouldn't fit to many foreign languages. For example, the capital A char's byte code is 0x41 and the capital Z char's is 0x5A. Then we have the √Å (capital A accute) which code in Unicode is 0x00C1. So a plain byte code sort would result the √Å to be after the Z. But in languages that have this kind of characters the convention is to put those with diacritics as if they didn't have the diacritic. So the √Å should be together with the plain A, at least before B. And to illustrate, we have below a list of names sorted using their bytecode: Brenda Debby George √Ålvaro √ârico Now using the COLLATE LOCALIZED it would sort by the "base" of the character: √Ålvaro Brenda Debby √ârico George" Thank you very much for your great work.
Manager.title: Names with accents (diacritics) wrong sorted in contact list

Manager.description: I've been using TextSecure/Signal for a while now and want to get more involved with the project. I figured adding fingerprint sensor app unlock support for the Android app would be a good first project. Before jumping into implementation, I found Issue #4439, where someone requested fingerprint app unlock as an alternative to passphrase, which was closed as wontfix. Was the reasoning for rejecting this feature request due to feature parity with iOS, placing trust in the OS's fingerprint store and authentication, privacy or security concerns, or software testing concerns? I'm not sure if the reasoning from Issue #420 significantly intrudes on the security levels I suggest below, especially when combined with exponential delays on failed attempts and database wipe after too many failed attempts within a period of time. This comes down to giving the user a choice of convenience and security, which I assume is why the no-passphrase option has not been removed yet. I was wondering if I implemented fingerprint app unlock if the Open Whisper team would be interested. Requiring both a passphrase and fingerprint is more secure than either one. In a public setting with wandering eyes, a fingerprint is more secure than a passphrase. Fingerprint sensor support would also allow quicker message checking while keeping Signal in a lock-after-5 minutes state. Here's what I was thinking of adding to the Settings menu always unlocked unlock with passphrase unlock with fingerprint or passphrase require passphrase every X hours (passphrase would be required after 3 fingerprint unlock attempts, and after any device reboot) unlock with passphrase and fingerprint (requires both to unlock the phone every time it is locked) erase all conversation history after Y failed unlock attempts (any combination of fingerprint and passphrase) Signal would use the Android Fingerprint API, using whatever fingers are registered with the OS.
Manager.title: Lock Signal with passphrase and fingerprint

Manager.description: If Desktop resets a session, the remote party will delete all sessions with our number, including any with the Android client. Thus, when the android client receives a synced sent message with its end session flag set, it too should close all sessions with the destination and render the message as Secure session reset. Currently it renders as a normal message and does not delete sessions.
Manager.title: Honor synced end session messages

Manager.description: The graphical symbol (pencil) of the floating action button in the conversation list doesn't make much sense. A pencil usually represents writing. But tapping that floating action button opens Signal's contact list (and is btw currently the only way to achieve that), which is not very intuitive. "Writing" in that context could be interpreted as e. g. a) writing a new message within an existing conversation (i. e. in the conversation list) or b) starting a new conversation (i. e. in the contact list). One the other hand, a plus sign ("+") represents adding, like in adding a new conversation. Within the context of the conversation list, I'm not aware of any other imaginable interpretations, so a plus sign is not ambiguous regarding its purpose. Manager.description: The recent commit 25d7931 uses the string "Signal system database import is complete." (I am aware that @haffenloher just made the already existing string translatable and replaced "TextSecure" with "Signal" - so not pointing fingers). "Signal system database" doesn't make any sense to me, i. e. having "Signal" and "system" in the same expression imho contradicts itself. There are a) Signal's (encrypted) database and b) Android's central database for SMS/MMS, which is used by other messaging apps. What this string means to describe is the process of importing from (b) to (a), i. e. from the system database to Signal's database. So this really should read "System database import is complete.", correct? While I'm at it, I'd rather suggest "Import of the system's SMS/MMS database has been completed." (this assumes that this string is the text body of a dialog - more space for more detailed info available - while "Import complete" is the dialog's title) or "Import of system database completed." if something shorter is needed.
Manager.title: Does the string "Signal system database import" make any sense...?

Manager.description: Non-international phone number are not supported (contact does not appears during a search) A mobile phone number can appear in multiple way here: +54 9 (area) (number) 0054 9 (area) (number) (area) 15 (number) (if inside Argentina, whatever the caller area code is) 15 (number) [if both numbers share the same area] Where "9" is the magic number for mobile (equivalent to the local "15) and "1" for land-lines "15" is the magic number for mobile (number) contains 6 to 8 digits (area) can (optionally?) be prefixed by a trunk code of value "0", eg: 223 == 0223, or 11 == 011 (don't know about the cases of the trunk code being mandatory) The area is somehow part of the number (since the number is registered for a unique and given area). But it can be omitted if calling from a device from the same area (similarly to the country code 54 which can be omitted if we call from a national device) Most contact's phone numbers are registered using the 4th scheme excepting contacts from other regions. The Android API already provides the country code. From this, it may be possible to know the area code (depending on the Android API?) From the above two it should be fairly easy to map phones number from one scheme to another. I don't know if heavy modifications are needed, but I could at least provide a PR to add test case. https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/blob/master/test/unitTest/java/org/thoughtcrime/securesms/util/PhoneNumberFormatterTest.java ? [edit] It seems that most of the country-specific logic should be handled by the libphonenumber, and more specifically https://github.com/googlei18n/libphonenumber/blob/master/java/libphonenumber/test/com/google/i18n/phonenumbers/data/PhoneNumberMetadataProtoForTesting_AR If it turns to be true, then what keeps the different notation to be understand as a unique contact?
Manager.title: Argentina phone number schemes

Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description I tried to get Signal working on BlackBerry's Runtime for Android. Sadly voice calls only partially working. I can call other Signal users but they can't hear my voice. I'm getting a lot of sendto() failed! errors in /dev/log/main. After some further debugging I found that sendto() always fails with error 22 (EINVAL - invalid argument). As far as I understand the code the socket is already connected in RtpSocket.java so a send() should be enough in RtpAudioSender.cpp. I changed sendto() to send() and got voice calls working. I'm not sure if this is a BlackBerry specific issue cause it works with sendto() on pretty any Android device. Steps to reproduce Install Signal on a BlackBerry Install Cobalt's Google Apps follow the instructions on Cobalt's official Google Apps landing page. You need to install Google Account Manager, Blackberry Google ID and Google Play services the Google Play store itself is not needed. Patch and install Signal follow the instructions on How to patch Android Apps depending on Google Maps and Google Play Services. Call a another Signal user. Device info Model: BlackBerry Passport OS v10.3.2.2836 Android version: 4.3.0 Signal version: 3.13.0
Manager.title: Possible bug in send() in RtpAudioSender.cpp

Manager.description: I would like to present one of our use cases for Signal (on Android): We use the app for sensitive information exchange, but would not only like the communication safe on the communication channel side, but also protected from people having access to our phones. Therefore we have set a password and set the inactivity time out to a low value. Often in a rush you might not be able to lock and close Signal and thus this is done automatically within a minute in our case. There are situations in reality where other people temporarily have access to your phone and therefore locking the app is very important ... Now we would find it very useful additional to the automatic lock after inactivity we could also set an option to automatically close Signal. In theory Signal offers everything to achieve what we need to be sufficiently secure, if there was not bug 3172, which leaves a screenshot in the recent app overview of your communication in some cases on Android >5, which happens regularly to us. An autoclose feature would also work around that problem, as the app is automatically closed after a set time out if we forget to close it. Automatically closing is very sensible from our point of view as it exactly does what automatically locking does: Making sure as much information as possible stays private ... an open signal windows in the recent apps overview is some tiny bit of information we would like to avoid automatically by setting a timeout. Of course if sensitive information exchange happens the user should be sensible enough to make sure he locks and closes the app, but in reality all of us are human and there are situations where auto locking and auto closing saves you a lot of trouble. I think this also fits well with idea of signal being as simple as possible to use. I agree technology can not compensate stupidity of people, but that's not what I am requesting. Furthermore it would compensate bug 3172 really well, as this would not have to rely on the ROM following the rules.
Manager.title: Request for enhancement: Autoclose Signal after set inactivity

Manager.description: Hi All, I was thinking that it would be cool to have a popup keyboard that opens in the app only. This would not be a keyboard app for android, really just a series of buttons that are displayed in the app that would allow the user to type "seriously secure content" without being tracked. I know that we could find a keyboard that "doesn't track anything" but it seems much more secure to have a internal keyboard that isn't a keyboard at all. Even if they say they don't track, you can't really be sure, plus, for most of my other activities, I enjoy the auto-correct and predictiveness of Google. Even most of my messages, I don't really have an issue with Google storing the data they store. But if I did want to send something I was worried about Google seeing, having a quick button I could click to open up a keyboard to enter a quick message would be amazing. Websites have done this for years, typically older government sites. They would have a little popup keyboard that you would use your mouse to select they keys to ensure a keylogger wasn't recording your social security number. Seems like a good idea to me, what do you think? I have: [ x] searched open and closed issues for duplicates [ x] read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports üëé 1
Manager.title: [Feature Request] Internal "secure" popup keyboard.

Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description Signal should fall back to periodic update checks when GCM Push doesn't work Steps to reproduce Tried installing Signal on a Motorola RAZR M, with Android 4.4.2 I have a friend with the same model, who also has the same issue with Signal I have followed all the steps here: http://support.whispersystems.org/hc/en-us/articles/213190487-Why-is-there-a-delay-in-receiving-messages- The RAZR M does not have any options for "Phone specific optimisation" When the screen is off, push notifications do not work for Signal messages (but do work for SMS) Only when the screen is unlocked, and the Signal app is opened, new message notifications arrive Expected behaviour There should be a manual option to perform the same routine as opening the app to check for new messages at a defined interval, say every 10 minutes. Messages do arrive, but only when the app is opened. To stop impact to other users for whom GCM Push works properly, this setting should be off by default This would mean that Signal messages are at least delivered eventually, rather than only when opening the app and manually refreshing Device info Model: Motorola RAZR M Android version: 4.4.2 Signal version: 3.13.1
Manager.title: Optional periodic check for new messages (when push isn't working reliably)

Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description I am not sure if this is a vulnerability, if it's a bug or a "feature". When using Signal as a default SMS app and enable the locked option, as far as I know, no one should be able to access any received message. However, if you have any two factor-authentication enable on Google (using Google as an example) and try to login to your Google account, you will receive an SMS and Google will automatically read the SMS and authenticate you, without any need of manually having to unlock Signal, copy the authentication code and paste it to Google's prompt. This should probably work with any app that will automatically read any SMS received to authenticate any 2 second-authentication code. This concerns me, because if I have any type of malware listening to my SMS app, it will be able to read any message I receive without worrying if Signal is locked or not. Steps to reproduce Remove your Google account from your Android settings. Make sure Signal is locked and is your default SMS app. Login to your Google Account. Wait for the SMS. Google will automatically authenticate you. Device info Samsung Galaxy S5 running Cyanogen lastest nightly build of KLTE. ** Signal Version: 3.13.1
Manager.title: App reading SMS when Signal is locked

To be honest, I recently disabled all the certs on my phone and started running apps one by one and approving only what needs approving. So far, not a single app did too well in these regards. A few even failed silently... Regardless, even if it's not worth improving on, I figured I should at least put it out there just in case someone runs into some obscure but related issues. I also saw the last few commits touched some elliptic curve cipher related stuff so this might actually be useful one day ;)

Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates Description My goal is to verify that the APK distributed on Google Play is executing the code at the commit of the release tag on GitHub. Even though I trust OWS to publish the untampered code, they could be compelled to alter it without revealing it, and it is better to know than to assume. To do the verification, I'm looking at the hash of each file in the APK I get from Google Play and comparing it with the hash of the APK I built myself. In build.gradle a timestamp is populated as a BuildConfig field at build time. This field has millisecond accuracy and is used to expire the binary after 90 days. Due to it changing during every build, classes.dex in the APK has a different hash, so it's impossible to verify the integrity of the code. Proposal I'd like to submit a PR to: change the timestamp to be granular only to the day (1458190800000ms). be replaceable by an environment or system variable. This would allow for easy APK verification. The signing date of the Play APK can be used to determine the build date which can then be replaced during a verification build. The timestamp can still be used to determine when 90 days have gone by and a build has expired. Risks The risk of this feature regressing in the future is fairly high due to the external nature of the verification. This could be mitigated by a build step that performs the verification, or reduced through good commenting. The code I'm using for verification is available here. Signal version: 3.14.1, and master at time of filing. üëç 2
Manager.title: Repeatable builds

Manager.description: I have: [x ] searched open and closed issues for duplicates [ x] read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description Android apps can choose whether their links open a new tab or overwrite any previous tab the app had opened. Signal should so the former, but does the latter. For example, if a friend sends a link to a newspaper article about how awesome end to end encryption is, and then while I'm reading it I get a message from a restaurant asking me to click a link to confirm my reservation, doing so will overwrite the tab where I was reading the article, requiring me to go back to that conversation, click it again, and then find my place again. This is annoying, and sometimes hard to anticipate (who remembers how they opened a tab four hours ago?) Steps to reproduce click a link in a message you received use the app switcher button to switch back to signal click a different link in a message you received Device info Model: Google/LG Nexus 5X Android version: 6.0.1 Signal version: 3.14.2 Solution You need to set EXTRA_CREATE_NEW_TAB. see https://developer.android.com/reference/android/provider/Browser.html#EXTRA_CREATE_NEW_TAB for details. I guess if some people find the current behavior preferable, this could be a configuration option, though I really think this is almost always unexpected behavior. I could send a pull request, but: I don't have an appropriate dev environment set up, and so would have to do so without testing, which makes me nervous. I can't actually find where Signal is calling out to the browser.
Manager.title: Signal should open a new tab for each clicked link

Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Enhancement description There are many sharing options in Signal, including sending of images and videos taken from camera or audio files, recorded by another application, but there is no convenient way to send and receive (play in-app) audio recordings, recorded only with the microphone. This is a very useful feature in bad connectivity or harsh audio environments, where live audio call is not an option (a very notable case being a warzone or aftermath of a natural disaster). There are also many markets such as Spain where people use this function on a daily basis. If the description is not evident enough, try to think of it as a "software walkie talkie", which allows the first Signal user to only press a button in the application (like "push-to-talk" button on a walkie talkie) and it starts recording the audio, which is then compressed with a suitable speech codec and sent via Signal to the receiving user. In this way the talk is not real-time, but it allows for disturbances in the connectivity between the two users and it also allows the second user to listen to the message repeatedly in case of loud audio environment on any side of the conversation. ps: Maybe TextSecure-Server would be a better repository to post this enhancement to, but it doesn't seem too live, and I haven't been able to found the Signal-Server one... If it's necessary, I'll repost this elsewhere, just let me know where.
Manager.title: Record and send audio ("software walkie talkie") for using in bad connectivity conditions

Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description Since I do not have a phone carrier plan, I use signal to send and receive messages over Wifi connections. This works because I have a VoIP provider with which I was able to go through the voice-based registration procedure (and thank you so much for that!). However, to send and receive SMS messages, I use a different app, which works pretty well. In fact, during the registration process, I did receive the SMS confirmation message - i just wasn't able to use it because Signal didn't intercept it. But that's fine as well because I could work around the problem. My main concern at this point is that I need to consciously switch between my SMS and Signal apps, based on whether or not I know that the user has Signal at all. In fact, I think there's a usability issue there, even for regular user: if Signal has trouble sending SMS messages (e.g. problem with the SIM card, connectivity issues), how does it tell the user? From my point of view here, Signal tries to send the message and I get the "bouncing 3 dots" forever, even though there's no SIM card on the phone and this will never succeed. What I would like would be for Signal to be able to talk to other apps to send and receive insecure SMS messages. I am not sure i clearly understand how the insecure fallback works right now - it doesn't feel like Signal uses the builtin messaging app but talks to the SMS subsystem of Android on itself. Could it be possible to fallback to some other SMS provider? I guess this also applies to competing protocols like Whatsapp or Telegram: what if my contact is not using signal? Could I still use Signal as a unified messaging app? (and coincidentally invite my poor Whatsapp or Telegram user to join Signal!) Note that other apps would need support for such process, of course. I have opened an issue for my specific app (michaelkourlas/voipms-sms-client#55) but I guess there would need to be such systems in place for this to work with Telegram or Whatsapp or whatever... Finally, I understand if you close my feature request as out of scope, but please do consider at least the case where the sim card is misplaced, removed, or the phone is in airplane mode. Usability could be improved at that level. At least having a timeout (or a shorter one, if there is one already) would improve the situation here. Steps to reproduce remove your SIM card register a SIP account with SMS support (e.g. at https://voip.ms/) install an app to manage SMS in Android (e.g. https://github.com/michaelkourlas/voipms-sms-client) try to send an insecure message in Signal Actual result: the message never gets sent and gets stuck in the "bouncing 3 dots" state forever (or at least, I have a few messages stuck in that state since saturday, so 48h+) Expected result: detect there is no SIM card and fail, or offer some configuration option to send messages through another messaging app Screenshots The above screenshot shows Signal functioning normally for secure messages, but shows the last message stuck in the "three bouncing dots" state for 3 minutes. Earlier in the history, there are two more messages stuck in that state from saturday (not shown in screenshot). Device info Device: HTC One S4 ("Ville") Android version: 5.1.1 (Cyanogenmod 12.1-20160323-NIGHTLY-Ville) Signal version: 3.15.2 Link to debug log https://gist.github.com/5b0303234463bc3ce4146f9bbec802e4
Manager.title: fallback to a different SMS provider than builtin SMS carrier

Manager.description: Bug description Last week I was travelling. Prior to my trip I had asked a question on the Signal site about migrating my session to my old phone (which would not matter too much if it were lost or stolen). The response I got was: You can install Signal on your other phone. Any new installation of Signal will generate new keys. However, it doesn't seem to be as simple as this. Steps to reproduce This explains my pre-travel actions: Install signal for android on phone1. Use signal for a while. Partake in private and group messages. Remove sim card from phone1 and install in phone2. Install signal on phone2. At this point, I am on the road with phone2. If you message people, they are informed that my keys have changed, which is fine. However, if other people post in a group chat that you were involved in on phone1, then the group is named Unnamed group on phone2 and the message entry box is un-tappable. You see messages come in, but you are unable to send messages. Then I returned home, and replaced the sim card into phone1. Now I cannot message anyone. The messages have a red message next to them saying Failed to send and Tap for details. When you tap, you see ( i ) Some issues need your attention and Failed to send. There is are-send` button, but it doesn't help in this case. Expected Outcome Signal should work on multiple devices per account (and it would be nice if it worked on tablets too). I think the issues I outline are because each user is expected to have exactly one keypair. This would be fine if there were a way to share a keypair between more than one device, or if Signal allowed one account to have multiple key-pairs. Maybe this design decision relates to the fact that a phone number can be active in only one device at a time? I also note that signal still works on phone1 which has no SIM card inserted. Not sure if that is desired behaviour(?). I'm not sure what I should do to get signal working again, please advise. Thanks
Manager.title: Moving signal from one phone to another causes issues.

Manager.description: Ever since I installed Android M on my Moto G3 I've had problems not filling my internal memory by accident, because Play Music now refuses to put my music on my SD-card. Ordinarily I can handle this quite well, with one exception.. Signal keeps using all the internal space, because everytime I send a video the app creates a duplicate of the file *_inside *_of Signal and I can't help but ask: Why? Why would I ever need a copy of my video inside of Signal? If you send a video you already have it on your phone, so why make another copy? The obvious explanation is that that way you know which video you sent, but really, can't you just add a file name instead? I think this behavior would be fine if I could put Signal on my SD-card, or if Signal could somehow only save transferred files on the SD-card, but in a world where internal space is scarce I think this is a really stupid design decision. Yes, I know about the feature that trims conversations and yes I know I can just delete the video from Signal after sending the file. But come on guys, that shouldn't be necessary!
Manager.title: Sent videos shouldn't take up extra space on internal memory

Manager.description: I would like to have Signal display read notifications to contacts that I choose. I have read the lengthy discussion in #957 about read receipts but since this is over 2 years old, I would like to reopen the discussion. From my point of view, having a feature that transmits information (like when a message was read) in an app that is about communication (i.e. the transmission of information) is a good thing. Whether to make this feature on/off by default or opt-in/opt-out is obviously debatable. My personal opinion is that I'd probably like it to be opt-out on a per contact basis, but to not change the current behavior for people from how it currently is, it would probably be more sensible to have Signal ask the question once per contact (when you start a new conversation) unless a default setting is set in the settings section. Even if the feature is delivered as off by default and has to be manually enabled, it would be a big improvement over the status-quo. Because (and I cannot stress this enough after reading through the discussion in #957) having a minority restrict the choices of a majority is the opposite of freedom and democracy and it seems to me these are among the most important things that free secure messaging is trying to protect.
Manager.title: Read notifications

Implement an option to use an offline mesh message network like e.g. firechat. firechat and the like use the phones Wi-Fi and Bluetooth antennas to transmit messages, calls and files without connection to cell towers or Wi-Fi. if more people are using it, it can relay messages through other users to the recipient (less server load). it could be nice if signal could send messages like: is local mesh-network available? yes: use no: ‚Üì is signal message possible? ues: use, no ‚Üì use sms. Why usercase1: privacy This will give great privacy reassurance. if you are within range to use a local mesh-network you can communicate "offline" with less chance of mass surveillance. Firechat was used for this reason during the umbrella revolution in Hong Kong for democracy and free speach. usercase2: travel/mass gatherings If you are travelling (to a country where you don't have a mobile plan or in a place without coverage (plane or underground train)) you can use local mesh-network messaging to contact people and to find people in the crowd of a festival etc. This would give great convenience, privacy, communication redundancy and save on you money on your mobile plan.

Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports For some reason, all messages delivered through Signal are slow to deliver. I say this based on the checkmark (sent/delivered) indicator, but also based on manually talking to a contact to figure out when things came through. I find that when this happens, asking the other person to send me a Signal message will force all undelivered messages to go through. In this case, calling through Signal doesn't work - it's just stuck at dialing forever (although it's possible, though unlikely, that I just didn't wait long enough). However, once pending messages are "flushed", calling starts working again. This happens both on Signal Android and a linked Signal Desktop. I've also seen it happen when contacting contacts on both Android and iOS. At least one of the contacts I've seen this with has been on Signal for months, and at least one contact I've seen this with had literally just installed and registered. When this doesn't happen, I find that messages will sometimes take a couple seconds to go through, but before I started running into this issue (which was a week or two ago), messages would generally go through almost instantly. All contacts that I'm sending messages to are in the same geographic area, so in theory we should all be contacting the same server region (in case there servers run in e.g. multiple AWS regions). (someone else now has your old phone number) (I think this could be easily reproduced without providers reusing your phone number and just putting sim card into some other phone) (TO RESEARCH: what would happen if new owner of my old phone number also registered that phone number with signal? Manager.description: I think it should be made more clear that SMS is possible with signal contacts, as it's not immediately obvious that you have to hold down the send button. There are a few annoying edge-cases that come up when a user doesn't have an internet connection. One, is that signal doesn't "remember" that it's sending a message. If you consider another platform like WhatsApp, if there isn't an internet connection, the app keeps trying to send it until it succeeds. With signal, if a user sends a message and forgets about it, it won't be sent even when an internet connection becomes available again. Another solution is to transition to SMS when there isn't a connection. Obviously a seamless transition brings forth security concerns, but a warning message alerting the user that a connection isn't available and then asking if they'd like to send an insecure SMS message instead could work. The app would display the messages differently and ask again after n minutes.
Manager.title: Suggestion about how SMS should be handled with signal users

Steps to reproduce This is not a bug report but a features request. Actual result: Describe here what happens after you run the steps above (i.e. the buggy behaviour) The feature does not exist yet. Expected result: Describe here what should happen after you run the steps above (i.e. what would be the correct behaviour) Ideal steps: In Settings -> privacy, in case a passphrase is set, provide a field "set deletion passphrase". It is assumed that in most cases the technical competence and knowledge about app specifics of enforcement is limited.

Manager.description: Hey there, I hope this issue is correctly placed here. I want to split it in two tiers: My perception of what the Signal client lacks to be even more user-friendly and easily adaptable, and my personal suggestion, how this situation could be improved. I just realized, that this is a extension of #838 with a slightly different approach. Its still a relevant and interesting topic, in my opinion. The Problem There is a huge trade-off between privacy / trustworthiness and usability (ok, this was obvious). I use signal ever since it was TextSecure and started with SMS (maybe 3 years ago?) and watched it evolve over the time. It continuously became more seamless to use but in my perception, some of this implementations are diametrically opposed to the reason, we all use Signal: privacy. And on the other hand, there are some features that are still very annoying, and I'd bet that this is because of the integrity of the encryption. My Suggestion Eliminate the trade-off between security and convenience: Every feature, that makes the usage more smoothly but on the other hand compromises security / integrity / privacy, should be opt-in/opt-out (with reasonable defaults or a wizard to set them). I assume, that this could help signal to differentiate itself from the competition (e.g. WhatsApp, Threema, Telegram), while makeing it smoothly and even more secure and trustworthy at the same time. Some examples Convenience features, that should be defeatable The sync of my contacts (and everything, that is connected to it): The option could be something like "Stop uploading my contactlist to the servers" - with an explanation what that means to usability. Annoying "features", that kill the user experience when re-registering or reinstalling the app, my friends need to manually add me to our groups. (My guess would be that this is because of the changed encryption-keys, however, it annoys me.) The option could be something like: "Ignore key-changes in all conversations" - with an explanation of what that means to vulnerability. What do you think? Is this even reasonable? Do you have more suggestons of opt-in-features? Best Regards!

Steps to reproduce Take a group message that failed to send to some users, but not all users. Click "Resend" on all of the users it failed to send to the first time. Actual result: So I walked around a large building that I was in, while on data, sending messages until one of them failed to send to some users, but not all. I then walked outside of the building, to where I had a good data connection, and pressed the "Resend" button on all of the users. Instead of re-sending to just the ones that were clicked, all users received the message, and those that had received it the first time, received it once more. Expected result: If a message fails to send to some users, when I press the "Resend" button to a specific user, it should resend the message to ONLY that user, or to all users that failed originally, but preventing the user from pressing the "Resend" button again, unless the resend fails once more.. Notes All users that have caused the spam have been Android users. I believe this might be caused by rapidly pressing all of the "Resend" buttons before Signal Resends the message. Manager.description: Deterministic builds (Gitian) is an excellent, decentralized, secure means of distributing binaries: Gitian is a secure source-control oriented software distribution method. This means you can download trusted binaries that are verified by multiple builders. Gitian uses a deterministic build process to allow multiple builders to create identical binaries. This allows multiple parties to sign the resulting binaries, guaranteeing that the binaries and tool chain were not tampered with and that the same source was used. It removes the build and distribution process as a single point of failure. Gitian is used in the Bitcoin project. Yes, there have been many issues (e.g., #122, #127, #281, #282, #458, #525, #722, #2858, #3435, #3954, #4429, #4430) regarding distributing Signal in other ways than via Google Play or Apple Store, but I do not think my feature request is a duplicate of those.
Manager.title: Feature Request: Distribute Signal w/ deterministic biuilds (Gitian).

Manager.description: While contact discovery is useful for the usecase of an average user just wanting secure communication with their friends, it is a huge security risk for activists. Although Signal is not primarily aimed at activists, there are no suitable alternatives on mobile. Are there plans to improve Signal in this area? Numbers are available to anyone in the group chat, so adding someone to a group requires you have to trust them not to leak phone numbers. There are no display names, so having everyone introduce themselves to each other is tedious and requires adding each other to contact lists, which is potentially a security risk as well. Global display names would not solve the problem, as you'd need to use a separate one in your activism group chats and with your friends.
Manager.title: Plans for Numberless accounts
