Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description When using a dual SIM Android phone, un-encrypted text messages (SMS) are sent from the primary SIM card even when all received text messages from this contact were received by the secondary SIM. Steps to reproduce SIM1 is the primary SIM with the data connection. SIM2 is the secondary SIM without data connection. In my case, Signal was registered using the number of SIM2. However, sending/receiving encrypted messages via SIM1 only works flawlessly, thanks! open existing conversation of a contact which does not use Signal (yet) this contact does only know my SIM2 number and thus, the whole conversation so far was written to and sent by my SIM2 send an un-encrypted text message without manually switching the send-button to SIM2; SIM1 is always selected and used by default Actual result: the contact gets my message from my SIM1 phone number which she did not recognize my text message gets misinterpreted as spam which results in a failed conversation Expected result: my text message gets sent via SIM2 (as before) and my contact recognizes my number IMHO, this can be accomplished in two ways: Signal asks me once (per un-encrypted conversation) which SIM I want to use for this contact This can be modified in the conversation settings Signal analyses the conversation so far and if (a) every or (b) the most recent ones or (c) the previous message was sent from SIM2, use SIM2 as long as I manually don't switch the SIM for this conversation. I'd go with 2. (c) because it seems to be the most intuitive solution without additional UI elements for switching default SIM in the conversation settings. Device info Device: OnePlus 5 Android version: 7.1.1 Signal version: 4.9.9
Manager.title: Ability to choose preferred SIM for SMS on a per-contact basis (dual SIM)

Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Not really sure how to report this. I deem that it belongs here since it is not a support request, and is an issue with Signal. But it it is considerably more general than other bug reports. I have read all of the issue tickets reporting issues with the new profile feature, and all of them identify issues with the way the feature was implemented. None of them speak to the addition of this feature itself as problematic. I use Signal because it is still the project with the most diligent commitment to smartphone messaging privacy. I have until now had high confidence that Signal development decisions would be smart and levelheaded, and would not compromise my privacy. The addition of the profile feature has shaken that confidence. The announcement of the Profile feature in Beta, which I've only now had a chance to read, claims "All of this is possible without sacrificing the privacy and security that you have come to expect from Signal." This is not true. Half of my contacts know me by one name, half by another. It is imperative that there is no crossover between these identities. Furthermore, the gmail account my Android phone is registered under is a third identity. Disclosing that identity to some Signal contacts would represent a catastrophic privacy breach, which could even, hypothetically, endanger my life. Up until now, there has been no cause for concern in using Signal, as enforcing the segregation of these identities has presented no issues. Signal's design decisions have never presented any threat to this segregation, because the presumption has always been in favour of privacy. The "set up your profile" wizard which announced itself after the update prepopulated the name field with the name associated with my Google account. It would have been very easy to have accidentally accepted this as my profile name. As per the Signal blogpost, this name would then have been visible to all contacts saved in my phone. This decision thoughtlessly left me a single mistake away from a catastrophic privacy breach. The "Do It Later" option was minuscule and dangerously close in the UI to the very large "Accept" button. It was initially not visible to me, so it looked as if I was being forced to choose a unitary identity for a Signal instance where I was managing multiple identities. When I did spot it, after a reinstall, several attempts to press it on my large smartphone screen were unsuccessful. It took multiple attempts. Before I discovered the "Do it later" option, my compromise attempt to save an empty profile returned an error message. I also discovered, after temporarily choosing a privacy-preserving pseudonymous profile name (which would nevertheless appear highly incongruous to several of my contacts) that it is not possible to delete an identity once chosen. There is no option to do so, and if you try to save an empty profile it gives you an error. So I had to reinstall the app to delete my profile. And when you do not set up a profile, the app harrasses you with persistent notifications to do so during group conversations, as if the decision not to is assumed to be a temporary one by the Signal devs. There are several bug reports which suggests mitigations for some of these different problems (although not all of them - e.g. I have seen no mention of the prepopulation of the name field as a concern). Fixing each of these problems would indeed have reduced the severity of the threat to privacy represented by the introduction of the feature. (I also imagine there are people who believe that simply adding support for multiple profiles would solve the issue, but in my opinion this would drastically sophisticate the task of managing identities, and result in accidental breaches.) But fixing each of those issues would not address what seems to me the major issue: that this issue was so thoughtlessly introduced at all. Yes, it is clear that - to preserve my privacy - Signal devs decided it would be unwise to just automatically create a profile for me based on the name associated with my Gmail account. Instead I was given a dialogue with the name prepopulated. But this in itself was dangerous, and the fact that I was subjected to even this danger with apparently no consideration of how it could affect people with multiple identities leaves me with little confidence that similar or worse breaches might be thoughtlessly created in the future, in order to introduce some convenience feature which is secondary to the goal of a truly private messaging application. Using Signal is now fraught with inherent risk, and I am no longer confident that Signal devs have my privacy as their priority. For me - a Signal user whose privacy is paramount - this profile feature is not a feature but a bug. The utility added to the app by the profile feature, eliminating unknown phone numbers in group conversations, seems to address an edge case at best. It does not enhance the privacy of the user - its only effect on user privacy is to make privacy compromise more likely. I cannot see how its addition necessitates the attendant complexification of the task of staying private while using the app. And the reasoning behind its introduction, in a dev team with a commitment to privacy, is entirely opaque to me. I submit this issue as a Signal user who values privacy, and who has experienced a privacy scare because of Signal development decisions - something which I am sure should be of concern to a privacy-oriented project. It is considerably longer than a typical bug report, because it speaks to a broader issue. If this issue can be taken on and used to improve matters, that is to the good. If it is simply the case that Signal is reprioritising, or that it does not intend to cater to users like me with harder privacy requirements than the average (but privacy-conscious) user, that is sad to me, but I accept it. But it also suggests to me that it is misleading to call it Signal Private Messenger, and to entice users with more stringent needs into a potentially risky situation. üëç 1 üëé 1
Manager.title: Overall Privacy-Compromise Created by Profile Feature

Manager.description: This discussion really applies to the entire Signal stack, but it had to put someplace. Also, I'm not entirely sure signal doesn't already have something like this. Signal does a great job at client e2e encryption. People mostly seem excited about it's ability to prevent people from listening in on conversations. Aside from encryption GPG also gives us verification that the message originated from a specific individual. I'm curious, what is that verification was taken one step further? What if a blockchain (of sorts) was kept for each conversation? This way, we enforce the order in which messages were sent and most importantly that message b came directly after message a. Deletion or insertion of messages after the fact would not be possible. Such an implementation would ensure a conversation remains the same between all parties involved and that no individual could inject or remove parts of conversations without the other parties involved noticing. An example of something like this is how git handles commits. Each commit contains a hash of the current commit (and diff) and the hash of the previous commit. A simple program can then run against the commits to verify the repo is in good order. In Signal's case, a central authority would be necessary. So the hash chain would probably need to exist on the server. The clients can sync against the hash chain and verify their local conversations match the server's. Thoughts?
Manager.title: Feature discussion: Blockchain verified conversations

Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description When Signal is used as an SMS client, it is frustrating for the user and the recipient of messages in which the recipient has Signal installed but is still using SMS. Many of my contacts have signal installed but still use SMS separately, or use iPhones where they cannot use signal for SMS. When a Signal contact sends me an SMS message, the Signal default is to respond via a Signal message, which is confusing for the other party and inconvenient for the user, who has to remember to change the mode to SMS. This discourages users from using Signal as their SMS client. Steps to reproduce Receive an SMS from a phone number registered with Signal. Actual result: The user responds with a Signal message, which may appear differently on the recipient's device and cause confusion. Expected result: The Signal app should either match the sender's mode of communication (perhaps with a warning about encryption) OR remember the user's preference for that contact across restarts of the app. Screenshots Friend sends an SMS. I reply in Signal without realizing, then re-reply via SMS. Friend sends an SMS. I remember to change the send-mode to SMS, but after an app restart the app is back to the default of sending Signal messages. Device info Device: Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge Android version: 7.0 Signal version: 4.12.3 Link to debug log
Manager.title: Messages send after a received SMS should not default to Signal message replies

Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description Android app is unable to send messages, open the "link devices" option in settings, or even deregister. Messages are received upon a reboot. Chrome app on desktop continues to work fine. Steps I took Earlier today, everything was fine, and I was chatting away happily via my Android device. I then chatted a bit via the app on my desktop. Walked away from my computer and opened up the Android app again and tried to send a message, but it failed. Attempted to retry, and it failed again. Went back to my computer, and sent a message via the desktop. It was received fine. Got a reply as well. Everything seemed fine from the desktop perspective, but none of the messages were received on my phone. Attempted to open the "linked devices" list and I get a "Network connection failed" error dialog. Attempted to deregister the device, as per https://support.signal.org/hc/en-us/articles/216948747-What-do-I-do-if-I-see-Network-connection-failed-, and I get "Error connecting to server!" popping up in the middle-bottom of the screen briefly. Rebooted phone, opened Signal, and the intervening messages all were delivered. Repeated above steps and no messages arrived on my phone and none could be sent. Actual result: The Android app only receives messages after a reboot, and cannot send messages, manage linked devices, or deregister. Expected result: The Android app should be able to send and receive messages normally, open and manage the list of linked devices, and deregister if desired. Note: I'm "still" using the Chrome app on this desktop, having never migrated because the standalone app's GTK usage doesn't play well with my KDE theme or DPI settings. I do have the standalone app installed on another desktop PC (which is how I became aware of the GTK-related problems), and the Chrome app configured on a ChromeOS laptop (which obviously couldn't run the standalone app even if I wanted to there), but I haven't had a chance yet to see if they are also still working. Device info Device: Google Pixel XL (marlin) Android version: 8.0.0 Signal version: 4.13.6 (from Play Store) Link to debug log https://gist.github.com/anonymous/fc26f282c52288f71392732eb86410f4
Manager.title: Android app no longer able to send, link devices, or even deregister; only receives messages after reboot

Manager.description: This may sound (and even be) overly paranoid, but the most advanced encryption in the world is meaningless if using an input method like Google Keyboard, with system-wide microphone access and other permissions. Tonight I had Signal open while watching a discussion on vegetarianism and magically I had a msg populated with "I would die I was sick of being hungry I was sick of beans and rice". I DID NOT write this, or ever discuss this topic with the contact. Perhaps it's just a random coincidence, but it sounds quite a bit like the endless reports alleging Facebook listening in and serving ads based on ambient audio. Regardless if it's a real security concern, it could be a potential one,. A few ideas: Have the option for Signal to use it's own built in keyboard, similar to those meant to circumvent keyloggers. There are apps like Microphone Block and Camera Block for Android which disable the microphone and camera on a system wide basis. Replicating this functionality in Signal for a "Get Smart: Super Paranoia Cone of Silence Mode" would be a great addition for those that trust Signal/OWS, but maybe not Google Keyboard/Android. This still obviously isn't a 100% guarantee, but could help shift the balance from ubiquitous surveillance to highly targeted surveillance (where it should be, and all we can realistically hope for)...
Manager.title: FR: Integrated keyboard input (Google Keyboard spying?)

Manager.description: I have: searched open and closed issues for duplicates read https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/wiki/Submitting-useful-bug-reports Bug description There are a couple of other issues (#6468, #5992 and WhisperSystems/Signal-iOS#2903) about this problem. One of them has been closed and the other two could've been filed in a more structured way so I'm opening this one hoping we can move this conversation forward in a constructive way. The problem is that Google App Engine blocks connection from Iran and this renders the anti censorship feature of signal useless for Iranian people. This is important now as the authorities are trying to shut down all the secure messaging platforms following the uprising and economical protests. Additionally, Telegram, -the main social media and messaging app for Iranian people-, has been blocked recently and this gives us a golden chance to help people adopt Signal. All it takes is to make sure all the Iranian numbers are being routed through a meek server that is not Google. We at Tor, have tested both Azure and Amazon and they work perfectly fine. I assume this is gonna be the same with other major CDNs as well. Steps to reproduce Try to connect to Signal servers from an Iranian IP address Actual result: Connection fails due to censorship. Expected result: OWS needs to either switch to, or add new meek servers on a platform that isn't Google App Engine and Signal should automatically enable censorship circumvention feature for Iranian phone numbers (+98). Device info Device: Any device Android version: Any device both Anodrid and iOS Here are some additional info for the curious mind: https://twitter.com/CDA/status/947556800328433664 and https://twitter.com/mrphs/status/947601608061353984 Please help us to enable and empower millions of vulnerable people to communicate securely with making this change. üëç 34 ‚ù§Ô∏è 2
Manager.title: Domain Fronting for Iran
